er 14, 2014
												To start off, I can't say that this is my favorite NFS game of all time, but it is certainly up there. I have been a NFS fan for a long time, dating back to the good old PS2 days with Most Wanted and Carbon. So far no other NFS game, in my opinion, has been better than those, but Hot Pursuit is still a lot of fun, and here's why.PROS:The graphics are fantastic. The car models are awesome as always, and the scenery is beautiful. Yes, scenery especially matters to me because I want to be able to go for a nice drive, if that's what I'm in the mood for. It looks great at 200+ MPH too! Now don't expect Metro: Last Light graphics, but it really is a nice looking game.There are quite a few cars as well. I can't say for sure how many there are, but it's certainly enough to keep you busy with trying certain races with different cars or just taking them for a spin. Not to mention that for every normal car in the game there is a cop car counterpart, with the addition of a couple! So if driving at 250 MPH on a freeway with sirens on sounds fun to you, please give this a try! But what about how they handle?I personally enjoy how the cars handle in this. It is NOT a simulator in any way. It is arcade style racing with easy drifting so you can boost into those corners like a boss without losing tons of speed or control. To me it seems like all the cars handle in a very similar fashion, but I actually don't mind it. I don't think this type of racing is for everyone however, but it's not hard at all to get used to. Remember that this game is all about going fast to evade cops or bust racers using special abilities, so you can't be completely focused on realistic driving. But that brings me to another thing I love about this.In the game, whether you are a racer or a cop, you have access to EMPs, spike strips, roadblocks, extreme turbo, and more. All these make the game more exciting and tense. If you are a racer, you can drop spike strips on cops OR other racers and use EMPs to pass someone, and if you are a cop, you use all of these to take down racers. I especially enjoyed the cop career more because it is really fun to smash into other cars and send them into a barrel roll or other cool crashes.NEUTRAL:The free roam is one thing I always want in a racing game. Yes, Hot Pursuit does have it, but I feel that it is missing content. Being able to free roam as a racer, you would expect to occasionally run into a police car and get into some sort of epic chase, or vice versa being a cop, but sadly that just isn't the case. There aren't even any collectables! I guess the free roam in Hot Pursuit is pretty much there to test out cars or just go for a nice ride. So yes, it's nice to have, but it lacks content.The menus are sub-par. You can very easily tell that it is more suited for consoles. While I strongly recommend using a controller for this game anyways, the least they could have done was provide a more intuitive menu for us PC gamers.CONS:With the exception of changing the color of the car, there is NO customization. I guess I "spoiled" myself with the feature of customizing back when I played on the PS2 because now every NFS game that has come out recently has zero options to customize, and it has been very disappointing. I don't know why they ever took it out.Now that I think about it, the menu tutorial at the very beginning of the game is really dumb and unskippable. It's like they expect you to know absolutely nothing about how a menu works. It is completely useless and takes a couple minutes. Can't you just let us play the game already?  TL;DR:NFS: Hot Pursuit is a really fun game with very nice graphics, great selection of cars, and tense racing. While free roam could have been significantly improved, it is always great to be able to go for a joyride in any of the vehicles you have unlocked, including the cop cars. Taking down racers or the police using EMPs, spike strips, roadblocks and more is very satisfying and really adds to the gameplay. There is no customization, with the exception of painting your car different colors, so this is a big let down, but nonetheless a very fun game. As a racing game enthusiast, I have to give this game a 7/10. Very fun!

												One thing I have become increasingly frustrated with when playing racing games these past few years is that developers seem to throw more and more crap between you and actually racing with every new release. Hot Pursuit may well be the pinacle of this. The races themselves are a lot of fun. The cars have a good sense of speed, the sound is great, the crashes have impact and the game is very pretty all around. The problem is that you won't actually get to experience these things much. The majority of your time will be spent watching unskippable cutscenes, loading times, logging in on your EA account (with no way to save your login details so you don't have to enter them every singe time you start the game) or being harassed by the game to check out its totally cool social hub feature where it pretends to be Facebook. And God help you if the EA servers happen to be down, in which case the game will try connecting to them at the start of the game and the end of every single bloody 2 minute race, taking 10 seconds each time. It really adds up to the point where 50% of your time with Hot Pursuit is spent looking at ♥♥♥♥ you really don't want to see. Why can developers not understand that when someone buys a racing game, the chances are they actually want to race? No NFS, I don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about your unnecessary Facebook clone "feature", I don't want to try and connect to your instable servers every 2 seconds and I don't regard your variety of spinning wheels in loading screens or unskippable cutscenes with particular affection either. Please make them optional so I can drive some fast cars without jumping through a bajillion hoops for a 3 minute race. Thank you.

3, 2014
												The Original Car Chase game, revamped... At least that's what I expected. Back in the '98 version it was a great fun game of racing vs your opponents, and the police - avoiding insanely high speed crashes and shaving that couple of seconds extra off a track, or getting a little nudge in at just the right moment, to win a race.Fast-Forward many generations of game development and hardware cycles, and we have the reboot. Initially it looks promising, graphically it's a lot nicer, the tracks are interesting, and they've kept the tradition of high-risk shortcuts to get to the end faster - but this is one of the things that shows up the games truly hideous faults.1- The enemies are scripted to keep up, not actually racing around the track as they look, but constantly teleporting around the track to be close to you. No matter how good you are, you cannot get more than a few seconds lead, even on a car you just saw crash into a virtually impossible situation, while you are at max boost - he'll be on your tail and overtaking the instant you take a corner less than optimally.2- Speaking of cornering - it cannot be done without a horrible skid mechanic. You just dont get to keep control of the car. At the time the game was made, drifting was very trendy, and the makers seem to have decided to make it mandatory for every car, every race.3- The collision detection is horrible for such a high end racing game. Often you pass another vehicle, or other obsticle, knowing you've cut it close, but also knowing you've missed, when suddenly the game decides you've hit, and not just clipped something, but catastrophically flipped your car and ruined your race.4- Hardware support. After a few months of having this game, my nephew loved playing it for fun, so despite not being able to forgive it's foibles, I kept the game, but after I changed some stuff on my system, it's refused to run ever since. Gets to the loading screen, CTD with no error report.RIP NFS memories.

												Hot Pursuit is a Need for Speed game in name only. This blisteringly fast racer has more in common with developer Criterion Games' own Burnout series than it does with any previous Need for Speed offering, despite lacking a number of features that are commonly associated with Burnout games. This isn't a game in which you're rewarded for crashing spectacularly or for jumping through billboards, but it is a game that encourages you to drive dangerously and to take down your opponents by any means necessary. The option to play both as illegal racers and as the cops that are chasing them brings some much-needed variety to the action, while spike strips, road blocks, and other satisfying countermeasures ensure that Hot Pursuit doesn't feel quite like any racer that you've played before. Regardless of whether your interest in Hot Pursuit stems from a love of Need for Speed, Burnout, or neither, you won't be disappointed.

content:
er 25, 2013
												This 2010 comeback of the Hot Pursuit series, developed by Criterion, is a great example of how not to reboot a game. Thankfully this game turned out to be very fun.In short, Criterion turned Need For Speed into a full-on car combat game. For those of you who were wanting a faithful follow up to Blackbox's 2003 Playstation 2 classic Hot Pursuit 2 will be greatly disappointed. If you come from Burnout 3 Takedown or Revenge roots, then this will be a tough call as well since iconic fictitious car brands and super accessible arcade driving physics are out. For those who love car combat or even kart and anti-gravity racers sub-genres may want to look into this game.Despite the fact that Hot Pursuit 2010 is rooted in reality, the core gameplay is about cops versus racers equipped with weapon loadouts duking it out on mostly point-to-point courses. There are a lot of mind games to be had, from intentionally driving backwards to strategically cancelling enemy EMP blasts.The driving physics are heavy and boat-like compared to past Criterion titles, but you can still swing your car left and right easily enough to stay in the realm of arcade driving. Once you engage in a drift, your car does feel significantly lighter so you can nudge your car mid-drift to slip through cracks in traffic obstacles. Swerving to dodge sliding spike strips isn't a trivial task however.As with any Hot Pursuit entry, you should expect to find plenty of exotic sports cars and super cars. What is interesting is that Criterion managed to fit in some very modest cars like the Evo, WRX STi and RX-8 without feeling out of place in a roster filled with Lamborghini and Porsche. You will be drifting on dirt and wet roads in the Evo and weaving past city cars in a police issued WRX STi. Speaking of police liveries, they look particularly amazing on the entire roster of the Law side. They don't all come in black and white either, expect some true to life palettes like peacekeeper blue, ranger green and even a patriotic flag on the GT40.2010 saw the release of Hot Pursuit by Criterion as well as Blur by Bizarre and Split/Second by Black Rock. While I do approve of this one-off reboot, some people may disagree because this does effectively kill off any hopes of a new Burnout game. Whether you love or hate this game, what is universally agreeable is that 2010 was a great year for racing game fans who crave for the return of action packed alternative racing.

												There is no NFS game that came after this that is better. This game looks incredible yet runs well on many PCs. In fact, it looks better than many games released since 2010, even games released in 2015 and '16. Here is a list of Pros and Cons, as I do in most of my reviews.Pros-Amazing graphics 6 years later, compared to other non-NFS games-Tons of cars to choose from (ranging from Mazda RX-8 and Subaru Impreza WRX STi to Bugatti Veyron)-You can play as a cop and a racer, which other NFS titles were lacking-Large open world (probably around 20x20 miles)-Lots of ambient sounds and awesome engine sounds-Special equipment for Racers and Cops (i.e. spike strips that can be deployed behind your car at high speeds, EMP to damage cars without ramming, etc)-Free Roam, which is great as you can just cruise in your favorite cars around a beautiful mapCons-The cars don't quite handle as well as they should, so you have to drift sometimes by briefly touching the brake then go around the corner in a quite-easy-to-control drift-You are forced to stay on the road and can't go offroad like in The Crew-Damage modeling is mediocre, a totaled car =  ONLY a cracked windshield, bumper hanging by one end, and some dents and scratches-You can't get chased by cops in Free Roam-After a certain point you can't get any more "levels" or "points", unlike in the 2005 version of NFSMW where you could get wanted by the police to the point where they chased you in Corvettes the second they spotted you, regardless of what you were doing.

A lack of modes, some rather bland race types, the always present rubberband-A.I. and a lack of challenge bothered me. But overall I liked what Hot Pursuit had to offer. A lot!

2, 2016
												People who grew up playing NFS Underground 1 and 2 will most likely be disappointed, since the focus on customization and 4-cylinder tuners that they know and love aren't featured in this game. People who know that Need For Speed existed before Underground will know that despite the powerups and pop music, this is the closest NFS has been to the original games in a long time.Gameplay-wise, from an outside perspective, Hot Pursuit does what an arcade racer should do best and focuses on high-speed driving above all else. Not only is the game arcade-y from a physics perspective, but it's actually set up kind of like a game you'd see in an actual arcade; you don't buy or upgrade cars at all, nor do you unlock the city part by part. You simply have a list of available cars, you pick what you want, and you start racing. I can see how most people would think that might be a negative thing (I myself probably would have preferred buying and upgrading vehicles) but I think the "quick race" approach works surprisingly well here. The driving feels good to me; the cars have a good amount of weight to them but are still easy to handle. Being able to play as a racer or a cop feels good too, and Criterion did a good job of infusing the game with some Burnout-influenced mechanics (such as takedowns and earning nitro) while still making Hot Pursuit feel distinctly like it's own game.The game does have some faults though. There's not a lot of content, there's no way to set up custom races, and the only way to escape police is to take them down; you're not going to outrun them because they're some serious rubberbanding ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. Also, there's other ways in which the AI doesn't play by the same rules; if a computer-controlled racer's health bar hits zero and they total their car, they'll respawn with a brand new one. If you total yours, the race ends. Being able to crash your way out of a race is totally fine (I like it) but it's always frustrating in any game when the AI doesn't follow the same rules you do. It feels cheap. On top of all of this, the PC port is pretty sad. It'll run at 60fps and 1080p, but the graphical options you can choose are very limited. There's not even any options for things as simple as anti-aliasing.All things considered, Hot Pursuit is a decent arcade racer with solid driving and mostly satisfying cop chases. The lack of content and barebones nature of the PC port are it's downfalls. If you want a fresh arcade racer, give this game a try...but only when it goes on sale.

content:
er 25, 2013
												It was about ten races in when I felt a strange sense of deja vu, as if I had raced these tracks before. And then it hit me; I had - back in 1998. This wasn't just another Need For Speed game branded with the name of one of the more popular iterations of the series; it was a remake! Now, you have to understand; I loved the 1998 "Hot Pursuit" (aka Need for Speed III); released 16 years ago, it remains one of my favorite racing titles (it was /the/ favorite until Porsche Unleashed unseated it two years later). Its great levels, solid driving, stylish cars and kick-♥♥♥ soundtrack combined into an overall awesome package. Few of the later games in the Need For Speed franchise even approached the heights achieved by NFS3. But aging graphics and finicky hardware requirements meant it was increasingly difficult to relive the original experience. So when I started recognizing some familiar curves and sets in the 2011 remake, I got understandably excited.Not that the 2011 Hot Pursuit is a 1-to-1 remake; it's more of an homage, utilizing many of the familiar tracks but updated with modern graphics and an open world. Still, it's a glorious return to an era of Lambroghini's and Porsches squealing unsafely around hairpin curves on gorgeous mountain and desert tracks. The car handling is wonderful; not in the least bit realistic, of course (I call it "pinball racing" for a reason!) but it feels very solid. The tracks are varied and beautiful, with a nice mix of curves and straight-aways, with numerous shortcuts to add some variety. But sadly, for every step forward the game makes a grievous step back. Worst of all is the AI, which is so tightly rubber-banded to the player as to remove all sense of challenge or achievement. How bad is it? Even when I cheated and disabled the AI entirely, my opponents were never further back than two seconds behind me. I never felt as if my skills were being fairly tested because there was never any distance between myself and the AI. It absolutely ruined the single-player experience. Almost as bad is how pushy EA is with their "Autolog" online service, without which a good three-quarters of the game is non-functional. I have no interest in the so-called "social" aspects of racing, but I'd have liked to check my race stats without having first create an account for yet another online service. Other missteps include an over-reliance on beat-the-clock races, a completely pointless free-roam mode, unskippable movies and an unbearable soundtrack. All in all, the 2011 Need For Speed Hot Pursuit has the seeds of greatness - varied tracks, good driving, beautiful cars - and it kept me entertained throughout its single-player missions. But it erred in too many other areas for it to be considered as one of the highpoints of the franchise.

I really enjoyed Need For Speed III: Hot Pursuit from 1999 and I think Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit (2010) did a great job to catch the old flair.The graphics are really good and the car models are highly detailed, nice damage textures included :PThe maps and locations are awesome! There are beautiful landscapes compared with nice weather effects. I also like the seamless change of climes. For example, you're starting your race in a forest and are driving the way up to mountains where you'll get suprised by snow laying on the ground.In the career mode you can choose between racers and cops. It keeps interesting because there are always different racing tracks and gamemodes. After every race you will earn points where you'll unlock cars which are divided in different tiers (sport series, exotic, ...). You can't tune or upgrade your car, you just choose your car and color.You can use different abilites while driving like spike strips, turbo (racers), emp or blockades (cops). These are limited and well balanced - they're keeping the races interesting and exciting.There is a freeride mode, but I think it's useless and boring, since you can't just challenge other AI drivers for a race or try to stop other racers as a cop. A "skirmish"-mode where you choose your map, gamemode and faction is also missing. A real shame, since the multiplayer is dead and you can't even drive with a friend against AI opponents.Another point which annoys me is the AI behaviour. Sometimes they are acting realistic and clever, making mistakes, trying to push you aside or are using the special abilities to stop you and sometimes they're just cheating. Even if they crash and felt behind, they somehow manage to get close or even pass you.You are using your nitro or turbo (special ability, more superior than nitro) and they just stick to your back like spiderman...They also manage to get around corners too perfectly, they even pass you in curves :DI know they did this because they tried to keep it challenging until the end, but even if it's an (unrealistic) arcade racer, I really prefer a comprehensible artificial intelligence.Conclusion:Besides those two points above, I recommend Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit to you guys.I had a lot of fun with it and I'm not a real big fan of racing games.In my opinion Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit is one of the better Need For Speed games after Underground 2 and it really honours it's ancestors Need For Speed III: Hot Pursuit (1999) and Hot Pursuit 2 (2002).

That game was awesome and it's the main reason why I've bought this one.The concept stayed the same - high tech super cars (licensed one and therefore - not too many bumps can be seen, although the game is delivered by Criterion Games) are racing down the road to the finish line. You're in one of those cars or you're in one of crazy hybrid police super cars taking down opponents by smashing into them, dropping spike belts, asking for road blocks and helicopters. Good amounts of cars and various tracks with shortcuts and traffic that can prove to be a determining factor between losing and winning are offered in this high speed arcade racer that stays true to original one (see I'm comparing it to 16+ years old game - yes, that's the one I've played like crazy). Sense of speed and tense situations are all there and you're gonna love every single second of it if you like adrenaline-pumping arcade racing games.The fact that needs to be mentioned is that you need Origin account to access multiplayer mode and yes, there are people playing this game in multiplayer which is unbelievably awesome.I got it for 3,70 € on the discount. If you're thinking about getting a racer or NFS racer to be exact, get this one. I'm not saying it's the best, I'm saying it completely satisfies me as a player and delivers on multiple levels.

												TL;DR version:  Good, wholesome arcade racing fun buried under in-game advertisements, unwieldy social systems, clunky menus and unskippable cutscenes.  Not worth buying even on sale (and I mean really on sale, $5 or less), unless you're very patient and don't have any better options available.Long version:  So, Criterion did the actual legwork on this game, which means the arcade racing is easy to pick up and fun to play with, the cars are pleasingly slippery through the corners and the crashes are spectacular.  The pursuit gameplay is basically just the races, only you've got lights on your car and the objective is to smash the other cars to bits rather than reach the line.  Over time various tools are added to amp up both races and pursuits, allowing you to foil tailgaters with spike strips, screw over those ahead of you with EMP blasts, and other fun things.  Said tools get upgraded and you unlock new vehicles as you rack up points for wins and completing time trial challenges.  So far, so Burnout.Really, there's absolutely nothing wrong with the core gameplay on display here, and I'd love to end the review and tell you to rush out and buy it.  It's an arcade racer by Criterion, of course it's good.  Unfortunately, it's been published by EA, which means there's a very large amount of unwieldy and unnecessary cruft not just weighing down the gameplay, but actively trying to prevent you from playing at all.Let's just walk through what happens every time you boot this game.  First, you're presented with an unskippable corporate logo animation.  Then, you're presented with another unskippable corporate logo animation.  Then you get an unskippable static image of several corporate logos and some legal text.  Then there's an unskippable animation introducing the title screen.  Finally you can press a button to proceed to the main menu - except first you have to get past the "Autolog" (social gaming feature) login screen.  You're not required to create an account, but they do their very best to convince you otherwise.  Once you find the "cancel" button there, you're treated to an unskippable splash image advertising Need For Speed World, an MMO which was cancelled in 2015.  Finally, after several minutes of wasting your time and advertising at you, you are deposited in the main menu.It gets better.  Or worse, I suppose, is more accurate:  The FIRST time you load the game, and the first time you access any feature, you're treated to a long, fully voiced, completely unskippable movie explaining what the feature does in exhaustive detail.   So the first time you load the game, you not only have to sit through several minutes of corporate logos and literal advertisements, you also need to suffer through 5+ minutes of being treated like a child who can't figure out what the shiny buttons on the menus do.Furthermore, every time you unlock a new car, or tool/weapon, or upgrade for a tool/weapon, or "rank up" your police or racer profile, you're forced to sit through yet more unskippable cutscenes as they loudly and lengthily tell you that you can now drop two spike strips at once or that you've now got THREE chevrons on your virtual profile.  A simple text box of "Spike Strips updated: Can now drop double strips" would do perfectly fine, but instead you get to wait through a full minute of animated guff pretending that there's a manufacturer making these items for you and here's how they work and here's some diagrams of them in action and I'D LIKE TO PLAY THE NEXT RACE NOW, PLEASE.It is, in summation, a game which does not respect your time, published by a company that sees you only as a wallet to advertise their other products to.  It fritters away your free time in dribs and drabs, taking several minutes to get you to the main menu, stealing away 30-90 seconds here and there to introduce new things in unnecessarily lengthy cutscenes, and chomping away 5 minutes or more the first time you access any feature or menu option to explain it in patronizing detail.  I bought this game on sale for something like $4, and I feel ripped off.Criterion made a solid game. They really did.  It's nothing spectacular, but there's also nothing wrong with it.  All the problems lay in the unskippable cutscenes, the unskippable logos, the unskippable advertisements.  It drains away all the fun and engagement and leaves nothing.   I haven't played the game for weeks, and I don't see myself going back.  There are better arcade racers out there that won't waste your time. Buy them instead.

												In short do I recommend this game? Yes I do. However I say this yes with a bit of a weight. You're going to have to like the game quite a bit to stomach the loading screens (and auto log into screen)...Anyway,In somewhat of a glorified version of Need For Speed : Hot Pursuit 2 - this Need for Speed : Hot Pursuit is a big update from the previously mentioned game. The graphics have been significantly upgraded and a lot of appealing cars have been added. Career is essentially overlooking the main map and choosing either police or racer events. Some events are a bit weird I found as I was finding myself in a time trial racing in a cop car. It made sense in a way sure you cut off some suspect at the end but it felt a bit gimmicky to me (I've mostly skipped those races and only done them when I had to progress to new events).As a racer your given abilities just like the police have. Jammer of course sort of stuns the HUD of your police car or disables cops abilities. There is a spike strip also available for racers as well as EMP. Racers also have the ability to have turbo which just sends the car flying.Police are able to use spike strips, call for a helicopter that can deploy a spike strip, call for a road block, or use an EMP as well. To be honest the EMP just locks on a removes some of the racers health... don't really like it. I personally liked back from NFS HP 2 you could call for a single car backup that would help slow down or ram the car. Driving is alright. This is as arcade as it can get. It seems they took Shift's 2 drift mechanism or something along those lines and made it the racing mechanic. Literally every turn you take I guess is mean to be a high speed drift. Again, this is where the original NFS HP 2 on PS2 or xbox was really good. Shift 2 for sure though takes the cake when it comes to driving games. Do I recommend this game? Well... not whole heartidly. I do like it but the loading screens, autolog, and the driving doesn't quite agree with me - so much that I'd rather be playing the game I mentioned earlier. The abilities are cool but I just don't feel the user interface is all the greatest either. No two player? Really? Of course you can play online but playing with a friend doesn't happen in this one. The issue also here is when you collide with a car - it doesn't feel like a collision. I don't feel the angle I hit at (P.I.T manouever doesn't really work) or how hard I hit properly registers. There's also the point where you can't simply play a quick race and adjust how many spike strips or road blocks you get. It's simply career with event races. This is why the game sort of has that gimmick feel to it. I feel a lot more could have been done here but perhaps given time constraints weren't enough. I'll recommend it but can't give it the highest of scores.RATING 7.1/10Gameplay B- Story / Campaign B- Visuals / User Interface B- Sounds / Music B- Replay-ability C+ Overall  B-

												There are only five reasonably bad things about this game:- You have to change affinity in the task manager on every startup, because this game has trouble recognizing modern multicore CPU's (this only takes 10 seconds or so to do).- There's an ad for the now defunct "Need for Speed World" that appears on every startup.- This game has barely any graphics options (resolution, gamma, shadow quality) and no AA (which is however easy to overcome by using nVidia's Dynamic Super Resolution or AMD's equivalent (this game looks great at 4k).- You can't access the DLC for this game in the PC version (not that I care about that, base game is fun enough)-This game has an in-game photo mode (which is great), but the picture that it stores is a heavily compressed 720p image. I recommend pressing the steam overlay's own screeenshot picture key simultaneously with the photo editor screenshot key, so you get high quality custom screenshots without the game's HUD.What does this game offer?A great ARCADE racing game with fun cars, a beautiful map (however empty in free drive), a good soundtrack and lots and lots of fantastic, unrealistic carnage (Burnout style, as many say). This game reminds me quite a lot of Need for Speed Hot Pursuit II (2002), although this one feels more action packed and nimbler. Overall this is a very enjoyable title that runs well on modern computers (once you adjust CPU affinity). Must buy for anyone who is looking for a great arcade racing game.

												I remember when Need for Speed games were good. For me it was about the time the first "Hot Pursuit" came out, circa 1998 (High Stakes in 99 was also good- I wish we could get the gameplay of those versions with the graphics and physics available today!). I think some of the others were fun too, but as time goes by they just get more and more bloated with silly EA crap and gimmicks. Hot Pursuit (2010) starts off poorly by demanding that the player sign up via email for EA's useless service (probably was to screw people over who bought the game secondhand). If you want to play multiplayer, better be ready to 'register' for no benefit to you other than making EA happy. Then there's an opening cinematic and long intro explaining the various modes and options, all of which is boring and unskippable. This must have been the time when EA thought it would magically turn into facebook by pushing it's social hub on everyone. It didn't work and gets in the way of the game, which seems like an afterthought given all the bloat that has to be passed through before actually playing anything.The driving feels floaty. It seems like you're either going straight or drifting (which is extremely easy to do) and there's very little in between. Nothing to write home about but passable if everything else worked. Collisions feel like they have impact although the damage modeling, if there is any, seems very oversimplified. The hot pursuit mode is where I really began to get annoyed because it was such a great thing to do with friends in the older games. Need For Speed III: Hot Pursuit was simple; you were the cops and used PIT manuevers or pinning to stop the other side. Or you played as the speeders the cops would try to do the same to you and use roadblocks as well. The maps were memorable and I still fondly recall some like 'Empire' and 'Lost Canyons'. High Stakes added a helicopter to outrun in addition to the cops which worked well. But by 2010 that wasn't complicated enough so now we have helicopters that drop explosive barrels on racers (yeah... seriously), EMP pulses, and every cop car is now equipped with nitrous because I guess everyone had a stiffy for Fast and Furious a few years ago and some guy in a focus group wanted that box checked. PIT-style manuevers seem not to work as well as they used to and it's easier to just ram other cars at speed as they now have a 'health bar' instead of taking location-based damage like in High Stakes. The whole thing is just over-the-top arcadey now, much more than before and to the detriment of the gameplay.

Overall it's a good game, though not the best NFS that was ever made but... there are some mechanics here that can't be turned of that make this game infuriating as hell the further you progress. Let me explain that: You have items in this game that you can use to either sabotage your opponents or the police. Things like Spiketraps and so on. You get the idea. This mechanic wouldn't be the worst thing ever if it wasn't for the random camera jumps that happen, when one of your opponents gets hit by for example your Spiketraps. So you are driving a race, you are barely in the lead, not only dodging the police but also the general traffic, you place down a spiketrap to get yourself a breather, the enemy gets hit and your camera instantly jumps to that event, shows it to you, giving the control over your car to the computer. It's offsetting as hell! It breaks the concentration, the flow of the race and rips the controll of you, sometimes throwing you right back, seconds before you hit a random car that you could have easily avoided otherwise. If it wasn't for this and the brutal AI (the further you progress) and the ludacris police-forces that annoy the hell out of you, this would have been a really good game. Sadly it isn't... TL:DR Good game if you have a very very very high frustration tolerance...

, 2015
												Although I'm not usually a fan of racing games, I've gotten years of fun from this one.  The game captures a huge chunk of California scenery from snowy peaks to seaside carnivals, and every area is a slightly different challenge.  Effectively, there's multiple single player game styles:Cop:-race against the clock with a specific car-bust speeders by smashing them with your car or various devices such as spike strips or roadblocksRacer:-A straight, no-frills street race-Racing, but with "wreck 'em" devices-Avoid the cops (sometimes with toys)Overall, the game is a thrill, flying along through beautiful scenery, keeping one eye on civilian traffic, one eye on your competition, and your third eye :) on the map to look for shortcuts.  Didn't enjoy physics in school?  Don't worry, because neither did the the NFS designers...you carom off guard rails and torture your $250,000 cars with no loss of speed or acceleration.  Breakdown:Cons:-Lots of menu screens.  This is partly due to the console nature of the game, with limited key options requiring multiple menus. -Lots of intermissions.  I'm guessing that the game needed to showcase each car in its stable as part of some contract, so you have to watch or skip lots of "car porn" shots of the camera lovingly sweeping around some fiberglass extravagance while a sultry female voice talks about "curves" and "power."  (Hmmm...is this a con?)-Spiky difficulty.  Time tests are by far the hardest modes, whereas it's pretty easy to get gold against five AI cars in street races.  Particularly tetchy are the cop time tests, where even the slightest brush with an obstacle costs you two seconds.  Plus, the cars you are forced to drive often wallow like pigs as you try to take a tight curve or thread some needle.Pros:- Great value for your money.  Get it on sale for less than a movie ticket, and it's an excellent deal.-A true thrill.  Every time a "Fast & Furious" movie comes out, I get an overwhelming urge to play this game again.  It really captures the over the top fun of the fantasy street race, where you tear around like a demon in unrealistically light traffic, bashing cars, going offroad to shave a few seconds.-A good family game (for kids over about 8-9).  I wouldn't use this to teach my kids to drive, but there's no cursing, the crashes are cartoony and bloodless, and everyone walks away at the end, even if the car looks like used aluminum foil.  My 8 year old didn't care for the races, but loved to pick a car and just free-drive the countryside.-Beautiful graphics.  Seacrest county is a buffet of Southern/Central California terrain, and there's a lot of little details which really make it shine (tractors, observatories, redwood trees, desert vistas).  [***Caveat*** Without a little tweaking the lack of in-game anti-aliasing and anisotropy will gradually drive you insane.  However, you can fix all that by adjusting your graphics card settings out of game.]-Cool multiplayer.  I never played online against random opponents, but my 12 year old son got a huge kick out of spike-stripping his old man, or forcing my Lamborghini to crash into an oncoming pickup truck.  Summary: Why have an expensive mid-life crisis when you can spend a few bucks on this game to drive ridiculously overpriced cars at absurd speeds in a consequence-free environment?  Sure, by day you're a cubicle farmer, or working check-out at Whole Foods, but in the evening, you're a live-dangerously street racer who thumbs his nose at the cops.  You know you want to  :)

content:
3, 2015
												This game is like a gorgeous airhead.  It's pretty, but it's also pretty shallow.  Actually, it's like a gorgeous airhead who won't shut up about her favorite reality TV show, but we'll get to that (the cutscenes issue) in a minute.The graphics in the game are undoubtedly beautiful.  I don't think anyone could argue against that point.  However, the gameplay itself is ultimately fairly hollow and weak.Admittedly, I haven't gotten that far into the game, but from the outset, there's really not much differentiation among the cars.  Or at least, given the events I used them in, there didn't feel to be a ton of difference.  The cop side felt like the most fun because you got to smash into other racer cars and take them out.  The racer side was just the typical stuff.  As you progress up both ladders (which you can play simultaneously -- which is weird), you also unlock various gadgets for different events.  Spike traps, roadblocks, EMP blasts, helicopters, turbo boosts, blah blah blah.  It's supposed to spice up the gameplay, but it didn't do a ton for me.Why?  Well, the game just feels...hollow.  For example, there's no storyline at all, so you have nothing compelling you forward.  Now, the other NFS game that I have on Steam is Undercover, and I'll be the first to admit that it's not like the story there was one for the ages.  It featured weak acting, overblown dialogue, etc.  But at least it provided you with...something.  Plus, you could customize your cars.  Yes, that's right. There's no customization in this game.  At all.  Well, not beyond selecting one of a limited number of paint colors for your car when you're a racer.In this game, you unlock vehicles, but unlike most other racing games I've played, you have no ability to tune or otherwise customize them.  You're also limited in your choices based on the event you're in.  You don't buy cars, either.  You just unlock them when you level up...and that's it.  You get some voiceover reading you PR copy about the car that sounds like it was written by the manufacturer's ad department.  The cars themselves handled...so-so.  They don't seem to grip the road particularly effectively.  You slide around a LOT.  Now, it's not as bad as, say, flooring it in a Forza game, but then, this game isn't supposed to be anything like a Forza game.  It's an arcade racer, not a sim.  The end result is that the cars felt kind of annoying to drive much of the time.There are two other really annoying features, though.  First is the game's built-in Facebook-like "Autolog."  Some idiot suit probably made the game developers include this, because it reeks of corporate brainstorming coming straight from the C-suite.  "Put in social media.  Kids are into social media these days.  We need it in our games."  "What?  But...it's a racing game.  They play the game to race.  If they want to talk to each other about the game on social media, they'll probably just...go to Facebook or Twitter for that."  "We need that, too. We need to keep kids IN our game, instead of logging out to tell their friends about the Bugatti they just unlocked.  They can do it in-game now.  It's genius!!  Plus, we can use it for datamining."So, you get a five minute cinematic that explains to you how you can connect to other players (which, especially five years after the game launched, is now pointless since I expect nobody is playing).  AND, you have to create an EA account, and log into it when you play.  Not. Cool.  To be fair, you don't have to be logged in to play the game, but the game throws this at you the first time you play, so the implication is that you need to.  It'll also search for the autolog connection for around 10 seconds, if it can't find it, each time you finish a race (because it needs to pust updates to your stupid autolog wall or whatever).Probably the most annoying part is all of the unskippable cinematics both before and during a race.  You can skip some of them at the start, but you're still forced to rewatch them if you want to restart the race.  I got this game for around $10 on a sale.  Maybe a little less, actually.  I'd say it's a so-so buy at that price.

												Отличная гонка из моей любимой франшизы Need For Speed. По сравнению со всеми остальными NFS, Hot Pursuit действительно другая, в ней нет тюнинга авто, нет покупки авто, нет занудных копов, но это существенный плюсы к игре, в ней можно действительно расслабится, поездить на хороших, дорогих машинах, при этом, даже не усердствуя в получении их, просто поднялся до нужного уровня (всего из 20), включил гонку или свободный заезд и получаешь удовольствие от хорошей графики и красивых мест. Так же в игре добавили карьеру за полицейского SCPD, полицейские машины также доступны для гонок и свободный заездов, это еще один большей плюс. Много красивой музыки, которую можно самому переключать, это тоже плюс. Мультиплеер же полностью зависит от уровня в компании, и доступу к машинам. Ещё она немаловажная вещь, так это перки или спец. возможности, как хотите, так и называйте, такие как полоса с шипами, эми выстрел, вертолет, и т.д. и т.п., очень помогающие при побеге от полиции. В общем, игра получилась на славу, всем советую, 9,5/10.

												With the exclusion to Motor City Online, I played every single NFS piece. While I hated so many of them, and praised with much glory High Stakes, Porsche Unleashed, Hot Pursuit 2 and Most Wanted, I say with confidence that this one is the best NFS I've ever played. Period. Nothing to question about.Visuals of the game are glorious, enough you'll love Seacrest County and will be exploring every scenery of it each race. But while the game isn't all graphics, the gameplay is also beautiful, and while you may find drifting pretty much like a hack and slash game which you press a button to backflip kill someone, you'll need to skill yourself in it and get better lines and better exit speeds as you play it. I guess the biggest fault of the game is the lack of a skill level on single-player, which is natural if you think this game is made to be played online with your friends.The car list is certainly beautiful and pretty wide, ranging from entry-level sports cars such as the beautiful Porsche Boxster and the Mazda RX8, from icons of Japanese and North American automotive industry to the legendary Le Mans racer McLaren F1 (not the GTR though, a pity) and the overrated beast Bugatti Veyron SS, and the best: All of them in a similar playing field. While you'll soon discover Reventón is a monster in it's class, picking a similar Lamborghini will get you covered to match the concept bull aswell.Well, realism, if you want it, go to iRacing. You'll be drifting a Ford GT at 150mph while the turbo is on (don't question how does this turbo works or go mechanical into it, just accept it) avoiding a spike strip that the officer ahead of you on a limited-edition Nissan Skyline just dropped on you. This is an arcade - treat it like as it is, please. It's Need for Speed.Want my final advice? Buy it. It's still a 2010 game, but still pretty much fun.

												(I mostly play on Origin, so few hours on Steam here.)It's Mario Kart with modern (for 2010) cars. No kidding. content:
11, 2014
												I'm not a huge fan of racing games and NFS series in particular, but sometimes I buy such games for casual playing.Last time I played NFS around 2004, it was pretty arcade, but with lots of carporn (not talking about streetracing crap, just the way cars look), dynamic gameplay and suitable music. I bought this game because I saw it in Steam after seeing a few dozens of positive reviews by series fans who were talking it's the best game in the whole franchise.What did I get? Disgusting music. Copy-pasted vehicles. Broken game mechanics. This game doesn't fit it's title at all: instead of dynamic races with smart opponents we are getting tons of catch-up, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ opponents who is just cheating all the time (if you are first and driving at 340 kmph it doesn't mean that some random half-broken opponent car can't outrun you, driving at 400 kmhp approximately). Game modes are mostly boring, actual pursuits take 10% of play time, other 90% is boring crap like races against the timer (for cops? really?). 1 cop vs 1 racer (and he will keep driving at impossible speeds easily going through curves without braking) and other kinds of boredom. In-game physics are bad beyond any point, don't even try to bust a racer by braking in front of him, he will just throw you away and won't get any damage), all vehicles have the same handling and differ by top speed and acceleration only (what is most hilarious, some of the cars doesn't have these characteristics in the description, having "classified" instead), it's almost impossible to actually crash (so you can forget about braking before turns). Also, the game is suffering from a major case of being overfilled with different opponent-side cheats, of course I understand that it is made just to made gameplay more interesting for a player, but sometimes it just looks idiotic: you, riding the top exotic car, cannot catch a guy who is driving some box-shaped american piece of metal, and even constant crashes can't keep him from winning. Another problem is cars. We got used to have dozens of perfect concept cars in every NFS game, but now we are having just a few of them, mixed with dozens of ugly american crap like dodge, chevrolet and other same-looking metal coffins.And last, but not least, is the gameplay itself. You will not get interesting competitions with different opponents, you will get hundreds of same crappy races on the same highways. By the way, game map seems to be huge, but actually it's pretty small and consists of same highways with different backgrounds. Which are, I must say, very scenic and beautiful, but still not capable of making this game any better.And a few words about music: I was never a fan of music styles and genres that NFS usually had as a soundtrack, but at least it was very good in pair with gameplay. In this game it's just a dozen of generic tracks from hipster bands you can hear on every generic radiostation.

content:
er 25, 2013
												Picked this up for 5 euro's which is about as much i would pay for this game.Goal:So, the goal of the game seems to be to reach the highest ranking as either or both the racer and the cop, unlocking new cars in the progress. You will achieve both by doing races, including a variety of new cars which you then can race with. Well.. which you can sometimes race with I must say, because for some reason the game has its own preferences for cars and in some races you are just left with 1 pick (while the game shows you more unlocked cars, which you can't pick for some reason). Then, there is no customization (sigh). A really big letdown for me, since this was what made the game series unique and was the biggest part of the reward system. This was what kept you playing, unlocking a new car, using your money to put some spoilers, wheels, neon lights etc. on it to make it your personal driving monster. Not being able to do this also made it less rewarding to unlock new cars like the camaro, which is one of my favorite cars.So what about the leveling system, or the ranking system if you will.. well.. you unlock new cars and some new abilities (which you can only use for specific races), but thats pretty much it.. I felt no difference being a level 1 or a level 4 other than maybe difficulty.. Its just not rewarding enough anymore, since we all expect more.. If this game wasn't part of the nfs series, it would've been so much better.Graphics:The graphics look average at best. I guess there went more time in actually letting players drive cars then the actual looks, which saddens me if i look back into the series. Most of the nfs games had pretty damn good graphics for their time, especially for a racing game. This wouldn't have bothered me as much if it were only the landscape, it is also the car models. I've seen way better looking car models in the older nfs's and I don't expect a game series like nfs's size to go worse in graphics.Ok.. so far for the bad stuff.. lets recap a sec: there is (in my opinion) no real goal in the game other than winning races and gaining rank. The rewards are race specific abilities and cars, which are less rewarding since you can't even customize them. The graphics are average at best, the cars being the biggest let down for me (graphics wise).The driving:So what is GOOD about the game, why should you buy it if you dissagree with the above? well..  the racing is pretty good, I love the drifting and the way nitro works in this game. It adds alot of tactic/strategy to the racing, which is cool. You can cut alot of turns or you can try and always get nitro back by driving against traffic, closely passing by cars and drifting (against traffic). Drifiting also is really important. You shouldn't always drift, and when drifting you get the choice of the optimal route or the route where you get the most nitro of.Conclusion:So its up to you. my advice: if you look for a nfs game, just stay with carbon, it had really nice driving, police chases were epic (throwing wood of trucs to cut them off etc.), customization was still in the game and the game had somewhat of a story/sense of progression. If you are just looking for a racing game, don't really care about customization or graphics, but just (unrealistic) racing. Then this is your game. And ofcourse.. if you have 5 bucks spare.. you can look yourself and see if you share my opinion ^^!

content:
1, 2014
												I wrote a "review" of this game almost 4 years ago, it was pretty barebones, honestly. I think it's finally time to re-analize this game again, after I recently finished the "campaign" again, for the fourth time in my life.Let's get this out of the way: This game is gorgeous. The cars in the game are gorgeous. The locations themselves are gorgeous. 7 years after its release, this game is still pretty amazing to the eye. The level of detail on the cars and locations themselves is pretty impressive. This game ditched what NFS had been doing for a few years, giving the player tons of customization and a story mode to finish. Is that inherently a bad thing? Not exactly. You get no story mode, no plot, no named characters, no car customization, and no car dealers. Just you, your car, and the road. (And a bunch of other racers and sometimes, the police too, of course.) Mindless fun. If you grew up with NFS 1, NFS 2 or even NFS 3: Hot Pursuit or Hot Pursuit 2, this won't bother you at all. Hell, it's pretty much trying to go back to its roots. The cars are pretty awesome without the need for custom paintjobs, different body kits or spoilers. You get to see them straight out of the agency, pretty much. Another thing that changed is, this game focuses a lot on roads, and not streets. There are less sharp corners than in previous games, and most of the map itself is littered with long straight roads and stuff like that, going back to the old NFS games that had tracks pretty much like that, too. Now, if you got used to Carbon or Underground, this game might disappoint you, because you can't pimp your VW Golf anymore. Driving is quite arcade-y, too, because you can go through the whole game without ever needing to use your brakes. You can just drift all the way, sometimes unrealistically. In this game, drifting is king. When it comes to Hot Pursuits, you get a few weapons to use against the police. EMP bursts, Turbo, Spike stripes and Jammers. On the police side, you get the same, except you get roadblocks instead of turbo boosts. This game also uses a few mechanics from the Burnout series, like driving recklessly to fill up your boost bar, or slamming other racers out of the way to win, which is rarely a good idea, you can simply outrace them most of the time. I feel like this change is pretty welcome. Free roam in this game isn't as fleshed out as in, say, Carbon. You do get to pick a car and explore the map, but you can't do anything else out there. Besides taking pictures of your car in different locations, of course. You can't drive manually to races anymore, you just gotta use the menu to pick your next race.Difficulty-wise, I find this game pretty easy. I managed to beat the game getting gold on every single race on the first try, except 2 or 3 that took me more than one try. The AI rubberbands A LOT, which is to be expected from a game like this. If you're falling behind, they slow down to allow you to catch them. If you're driving perfectly and at top speed, they will be poking your ♥♥♥ often. Often, but not always. Once you get used to drifting and a few other basic tricks in the game, it's pretty much a piece of cake.Complaints? I've got a few. First of all, you can't skip cutscenes, no matter how many times you've watched them before. It's ♥♥♥♥ing annoying going over the same cutscene explaining you the new weapon you've got even if you already know how to use it, and if you've watched that video dozens of times already. With all the adrenaline inducing races, I feel like this ruins the pace a bit.Second, this seems like a bit of a nitpick, but I'm gonna say it anyways: I really like the soundtrack of this game, it's got a few songs that I hate, but most of the other ones are okay in my book. The problem is, when you're playing as the police and you're chasing somebody, or you're being chased yourself, the soundtrack abruptly stops. Instead of that awesome song you love that would make the chase way more epic, you get cliche Hollywood stock music, pretty much. I find the chase music rather lame, and there's no way you can change it. Lame.And third, all of the DLC cars in the PC version are missing, as far as I know. There's a bunch of awesome cars (Like the Lamborghini Countach and the Lamborghini Diablo) that you  can't use in this game at all, because they just aren't in the game. Screw you EA, you could've drained some extra cash from my pockets, but your store doesn't even work. All in all, I feel like the price of the game is somewhat acceptable. The game's kinda short, you can probably finish the campaign in less than 10 hours, and you can reach max level with both racer and police in about 20 hours or less. Still, if you see it on sale, I'd recommend picking it up. It's mindless fun in lieu of the old Need For Speed games.

★★★☆☆There are three reasons I felt sour about this game, two of which you can almost ignore. The first was the stutter problem. It turns out that this game doesn't run properly on quad-cores (yeah, seriously). This is fixed with 'lil program called Lasso. The second sour feeling is the online feature: the EA (dot com) servers went offline somewhere in 2016. I used my steamkey prior that year and now I can't tie the key to my origin account. EA support, disappointingly, doesn't respond after several attempts. Now I know how stale this game actually is without the online features. This leads to my current and definitive sour feeling on this game.Good things out of the way first: it runs really smooth, the crashes look cool, the environments look pretty (desptite the extremely wide roads) and there is a great sense of speed. The controls - a mixture of boosting and drifting - are really satisfying when you get the hang of it. The two feed eachother and it rewards you for doing it correctly. Another important note is the satisfying ability to call in a helicopter that flies extremely low to ground above you. It's definitely the highlight of the game for me.However, the singleplayer is somewhat repetitive. Although the developers try to mix up the game with different modes you've to pass before continuing, I couldn't sometimes bare ANOTHER Time Trial or another one-on-one event. Eventually, I gave up on the game at around the 50% mark, because the modes and tracks just aren't divers or interesting enough to invest time and effort in. Another reason for bailing was the constant, un-f***ing-skippable 'unlock' videos, that would show you what new car you can use or what perk got upgraded. The last one specificly is just non-sense, since contentually it bares no meaning to you as a user. These videos are especially jarring in the first three hours of playtime, when it feels like it never stops. It's even more aggrevating to think about it when you realise that a lot of events only let you use a select number of cars or even just one of them... Another game from these developers, called Burnout Revenge, suffered from the same syndrome, yet I adore that game, mainly because it wasn't just another simple racer.Burnout Revenge was also better for another reason. A small, yet a really important reason: the ability to turn OFF crashcam. This is the camera that takes your view away from your own car, just to show a car that you made crash a split second before. When the camera turns to you again, there is a small chance that you bump into a wall or into another car. Not only does this camera remove the sense of speed and chaos, it also got in my way of performing well. A real bummer.Fun can be had with this speedy racer, if you turn on your own music and ignore the cheap sounding tv-quality music and voice-acting of the game. But in 2017 we got better options, sometimes even for free (like the latest Need for Speed through Origin). Hot Pursuit certainly isn't bad, but I don't see much reason to recommend it the people today.

content:
er 25, 2013
												Need For Speed III: Hot Pursuit was one on my favorite games back in the old Need For Speed days. When they announced the revive of the Hot Pursuit series back in 2010, I was pretty excited. Driving in a high speed chase from the cops was a fun experince to have. Having to be the cop was a great experince to have if you want to be with the law and wrecking racers. There's a big list of cars ranging from everyday cars to one the most exotic and expensive cars in the world. They all have their unique characteristics of thier driving in Seacrest County. From the bulky Dodge Charger SRT8 to the lightweight Koeningsegg CCXR Edition. The county of Seacrest is a beautiful resemblance of four different enviroments mashed together with one of the most exhilerating roads I've seen in a modern Need For Speed game. The sounds in this game is mindbolowing. Where my head just couldn't handle it and I had to stop and catch myself before I pass out. Ok I'm kidding on that but really the vehicle sounds is really amazing.GraphicsFor a 2010 game, I have to say that this game itself is a pleasuring beauty. All enviroments ranging from the mountains to the desert have a beautiful scenery that keeps the driver in awe while driving in a intense race. The details of each vehicle is really amazing with high tessellation that helps the vehicle look more realistic and more immersive to drive. The carbon fiber on the Koenigsegg CCXR for example is just amazing. The lighting effects is just beautiful from day to night. The weather effects has got to be the best I've seen so far in a Need For Speed game. Seeing the relfection on the wet surface is really fantastic. The textures of the road is just amazing with each road having their own unique style to it. Also since this game is made by Criterion games. It's not surprising that the damage model is just jawdroping from every crash that you witness. The only complaint I do have to say is that theirs no Anti-Aliasing to be found in the game.GameplaySince this game is supposed to bring back the original Hot Pursuit feel, there's obviously not going to be any customization. Which some people would complain but since all of this was based before Underground 1 and 2 it would make sense. Color picking has been reduced to manufatured paint only which is a bit disapointing. For the driving part, it's pretty fun driving every vehicle since they do have their own unique handling and drifting. What I thought was pretty interesting that the devopers added weight to the driving which makes it more realistic. For instance the Bentley Continental Coupe is a pretty heavy vehicle. It's pretty difficult to swerve the vehicle from left to right since it's a heavy car. For the Pangani Zonda Cinque, it's nimble so the car can swerve easily around traffic and the cops. This new pursuit weapon that Criterion Games added is a pretty cool feature. Each side (racer/cop) has some unique features that only one side can use (For instance cops can call in road blocks or a helicoptor whereas the racer can use either a jammer or turbo). In my opinion they'll seem to be balanced in a nice mannor. Freedrive is a decent experince since the player can use freedrive to test drive the car without having to deal with cops/racer or crashing out. The main downside is that since there's no option for a online freedrive, the replayability of that mode is small. This new social feature, Autolog, is a really nice feature that let's the player challenge their freinds, share photos and disscus. The downside to this is that people that has little to no friends will think that this feature is useless to them, but it's a not a flaw by any means. DLC wise..... well there's no DLC here becuase we know that EA doesn't like PC players that much besides Battlefield.ConclusionThis game is a great succesor to the past Hot Pursuit games and I feel like this game is great for any casual or competitive players.PO. Trying this little feature out that Steam released and I thought that it would be cool to do this. :)

y 24, 2015
Intro:Before Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit, I hadn't played a racing game since.. Underground 2?I was curious what the racing genre was like nowadays. Unfortunately, my selection was this title.Remember Hot Pursuit 2? That game was pretty cool for the time. It had a good selection of cars, some decent campaign challenges, fair visuals, an awesome soundtrack, and a expansive free mode/ multiplayer. With a bunch of rules and modes to choose and customize, it was a bunch of fun. Yeah, this game is nothing like that.Gameplay:So the singleplayer consists of you going through different maps and completing challenges, much like the original. The vehicle selection is extremely slim, but's alright since we can play free mode for that stuff! Right?...Anyway, there's not much to say about the campaign mode other than its pretty bare. Some levels are normal races, there's cop chases, about everything you'd expect.The problem is its all so damn boring.They tried to add some arcadey elements like dropping spike traps behind your car, but it just felt incredibly dull. I can say something positive - the sense of speed feels pretty good. The racing itself is fine really, but its just a boring game.What about the free play? You know, picking out a car from a huge list, setting up a game mode such as knockout or chase, picking a level, choosing the laps and difficulty, all that good stuff. What's that like in this game?IT ISN'T IN THIS GAME.I'm not even ♥♥♥♥ing joking. Okay, there's a multiplayer mode that likely includes all this stuff, but what the hell? We can't even race offline? If I recall, the multiplayer servers have been offline for ages anyway so what do you have left?An incredibly lacking single player campaign.Story, Visuals, & Music:Story = None. I think. If there was one, it was awful.Visuals = Pretty good.Music = The older NFS games have always delivered on the music. Up-beat tracks that really set the racing feel. Yeah, this game greets you with a title screen that is as dark and depressing as the fact this game exists. The music that plays in-game is decent at best, but nothing memorable at all. Oh wait, I think there was a Skrillex track in there!...PC Version:Game runs fine, but multiplayer is dead.Conclusion:The whole game is incredibly bland. There's no redeeming traits here. It's a terrible game that is an insult to the original Hot Pursuit games.Maybe I didn't give it enough of a chance but I found myself sick of playing it.This game just isn't very good and there are much better racing games out there.If you want something cheap, arcadey, and a ton of fun checkout Burnout: Paradise. That game is awesome and still has people playing its multiplayer.If you want something a bit more expansive, I really enjoyed The Crew but there's a ton of good options.If you want your racing fix, pick anything other than this.

content:
y 5
												The last NFS games I had played before this, were Underground, Underground 2, and Most Wanted (2005)- so my standards for this game may have been a little high.  It's sorely lacking numerous aspects which I LOVED about previous installments in this series.[CONS]- No open world.  Just an overview map which you use to select races.  No sense of immersion at all.  In comparison, Most Wanted and Underground 2 had cut scenes, phone calls/texts from other characters and an open city you could explore which made it feel like you were a part of that world.- No car customization/upgrading.  You have no options to improve the style or performance of your vehicle, aside from choosing the paint color.  But you can't really personalize it or make it unique in any way.  You don't even have to buy new cars...they are given to you each time you reach a certain Warrant level.- 95% of the race is useless.  It doesn't matter how well or poorly you drive for most of the race, as long as you just don't screw up the last 1 - 1.5 miles, you'll win.  I crashed like 5x once, while being chased by the cops (never got arrested for some reason) but still managed to catch up to the NPC racers and win.  On the other hand, I've also ran a perfect race while the NPC racers kept crashing behind me (yet I could never make distance from them), only to mess up in the last mile and lose.  So unless you're doing a Time Attack type race- however you drive the first 95% of the race, whether you take shortcuts or use nitrous or slipstream, it doesn't matter.- Race Locks.  Certain cars can only be used for certain races.  I wouldn't mind SOME races to be vehicle specific, such as a Roadsters Only race for example, but all the races in this game are locked for certain cars only, usually by class (Sport, Performance, Super etc).  We should have the option to use the Super Cars we unlock to beat up on Sport Cars if we want!- No instant replay/race replay.  Sometimes when you have a sweet takedown, you want to be able to rewatch with satisfaction wrecking someone else.  Or sometimes, you just want to watch a replay of the race to see where you messed up and what you could have done better.  Sorry, but you can't do that here.[PROS]- Graphics.  Despite the game being a few years old, the graphics still look pretty good.- Controls.  The controls are simple and easy to learn.  Each car handles a bit differently, but it doesn't take long at all for you to get a feel for each one and adjust your braking/turning accordingly.I hate to say it, but overall this game is pretty shallow.  I would rather play Need For Speed III: Hot Pursuit for PS1, than this version.  That game had a lot more depth!

content:
, 2016
												TL;DR an OK game, get while on sale, if you're a fan of classic NFS games, expect non-stop facepalm.some background. i am a long time fan of NFS series. i've spent countless childhood hours playing NFS 2, 3 (aka the original HP), 4 and 5 on PS1. i've been a huge fan of NFS 6 (aka HP2), and still play it regularly to this day.however, unlike most people, i never liked the "Fast and Furious" movie franchise, and i was never a fan of this "street racing" theme that started popping up in racing games shortly after the movie was released, and so i was never a fan of NFS Underground (and onwards). i felt completely betrayed by the series, so much that i not only didn't play any new NFS games since HP2 was released, but didn't even care to look if there were other NFS games released in the meantime (i stopped caring after the original Most Wanted came out).to be fair, i don't blame other people for liking it, and i certainly don't blame EA for trying to cash in on this newfound commercial success of everything "street racing", it just wasn't my thing, so i just quietly walked away when it started to look like i ain't getting any more classic racing games from NFS franchise.but yesterday, i found out about this game. i'm 6 years late to the party, but by the time it was released, 8 years have passed since NFS HP2, so i guess another 6 didn't make much difference. so, let's start with the good parts.the graphics are great. like really, really great - the picture is magnificent, both in terms of cars and in terms of the environment. HDR, wet roads, lights, rain all look impressive and realistic. crashes are spectacular, and the damage to the car actually makes at least some sense (the awkwardness of car damage is just about the only thing i dislike about NFS HP2).the concept of the game is where it's at for classic racing games - no "story", no "progression", no "customization", simple "win this race to unlock more tracks/cars". this may seem boring to a lot of younger NFS fans who grew up with NFS:U, but this is what actually makes a great classic racing game. and this is what drew me in to this game in the first place, as i have given up hope on NFS ever returning to their roots of joyriding on supercars, with none of that "illegal racing" shtick.(to be fair, most pre-NFS:U games had cops, and the fact that they were chasing you meant that technically, the racing was illegal as well. the difference is, you didn't feel like being an actual criminal, being in a gang or a "racing crew" and all that; it just felt like racing scenic routes, but with cops on your tail as a nuisance)technically speaking, execution is flawless - i didn't notice any glitches or bugs, game runs smoothly on highest settings, the controls are pretty responsive (more on that later). so nothing to complain on this front either.good parts end here, and what follows is all bad parts.first of all, soundtrack. i'm more of a classic rock fan, but even through NFS HP2 didn't have any of that, it still had a cool adrenaline-infusing, loud and fast rock soundtrack. at least it lent itself well to driving fast while listening to it. none of that here - music in this game makes me want to sleep, not drive. and to top it off, there is absolutely no way of changing the music, so you have to resort to running a music player in the background. this was an extremely stupid move by EA - i understand that everyone's tastes are different, but can we at least have custom music in-game without resorting to workarounds?next thing, physics. it sucks. it feels completely console-y and arcade-y. and in a bad way. NFS never was a driving simulator, but this is way too far. use handbrake, the car just turns 90 degrees, and you're good to go, the car is perfectly stable again, as if it didn't just go forward at 250+ km/h. that's not what happens in real life, you know. it's called inertia, look it up. and because of that, every car essentially drives the same - there's not much difference between a BMW and a Lamborghini, aside from speed. hit gas, hit handbrake once in a while, hit nitro on long straights. done. no personality to cars whatsoever.aside from that, the braindead NFS Underground et al game mechanics are present here as well, albeit to the lesser extent. you still have nitro, so the game is now down to not "who drives better", but "who knows how to use nitro better". at least in NFS:U you had to *buy* nitro, and could only use it once in the race. nitro as it is in this game makes no sense whatsoever.also, courtesy of NFS:U, you still have "drifting" as well. why?! it's a flashy gimmick! drifting kills your tires, not one proper racer in their right mind would intentionally drift that much on tarmac! but here, not only it's a game mechanic (as opposed to simply being a natural consequence of the game's physics, like in NFS 6), it's actually encouraged.you'd think that at least the cops pursuits would be great, right? being all "back to the roots" and stuff. but no, cop chases have their fair share of stupidity as well. first of all, the "takedowns". i get it, it looks flashy when you barely scratch a rival's (or cop's) car and it suddenly goes spinning into the side of the road for some reason, but why does this only happen in cop chases? what, laws of physics suddenly change when cops are on the road? try doing a takedown in a regular race - no luck, you'd just hit a rival's car and lose speed.not only that, but why do i have weapons? i am getting away from cops, yet *i* can spike them? i mean, i'm all for role reversal if the partner is willing, but this is too far into the Rollcage territory. this is the stupidest idea i've seen so far in an NFS game.there are other various little bits that are annoying and stupid as well: the constant camera shifting, which is very pace-breaking; the inability to do custom single races and time trials; the stupid commentary that can't be skipped over; this newfangled "online" "social" thingie that nags you every time; the AI magically catching up to you when you're driving at max speed on a long straight...and the most stupid part: you can't actually get arrested by cops. you drive at 300 km/h, you hit a cop roadblock, you spin away, stop on your roof... and then you happily respawn and drive away again, like nothing ever happened! like you didn't just STOP, surrounded by a bunch of cops, which would've got you arrested in a second if it was NFS:HP2! but no, in order to actually be caught, apparently you have to destroy your car. that's beyond stupid. that destroys the whole purpose of the races with cops.finally, the whole "open world" thing. an "open world" basically means "one big track". and while the scenery can be varied, it can't be compared to the joy of driving around different countries, different continents and different cultures. i don't want to drive around a single US state which, for some reason, comprises just a bunch of highways, i want to visit many different places! you've got this beautiful graphics engine, and you're wasting it all away on one single scenery!so, in conclusion, IMHO NFS:HP2 still remains the undisputed king of classic NFS series. it strikes just the right balance of not being too old (and thus having blocky graphics and wonky physics) and having all the classic gameplay elements of a proper racing game - long varied tracks with beautiful scenery, great cars, and cops. this game fails to dethrone it. it may be a step in the right direction... but no cigar, not by a mile.

content:
