OVERVIEWNeed for Speed: Hot Pursuit is a multi-award winning racing game, developed by Criterion and published by 	EA. Criterion knows how to make racing games fun. What more do you want?But there is never much to say about racing games, mainly because they’re all the same. Pick a vehicle, pick a stage, go really fast and try to win. The only real differences between racing games are vehicle handling, race types, and the usual features, like “powerups” or rewinds.VEHICLE HANDLINGWhen it comes to vehicle handling, racing games either opt for a more realistic feel, focusing on simulating real life, or they opt for an arcade feel, focusing on actually making the game fun. NFS:HP is nothing more than an arcade racing game, but if it does anything good, is nailing the arcade feeling. Boy does it feel good to drift around every corner at +300km/h using nitrous, while avoiding cars in oncoming traffic.RACE TYPESWhen it comes to race types, more doesn’t always make better. I rather have few but fleshed out race types, than having multiple race types that don’t work or are boring to play. And with that said, most race types in NFS:HP feel just like any other race game, ever. BUT, there’s a twist, because in NFS:HP, not only you play as a racer, but you can also play as a cop. Racer RacesWith racer you have what you expected, you have your normal sprint races, time trials and duels, but where it gets better is when the game throws those normal modes, and makes them even harder. Hot Pursuits, are just like sprint races, but with police force trying to stop every racer, while making you outrun cops by using powerups. [Check out Equipment Section] Previews, which are like time trials, but with end game cars the game forces you to use, where you get penalized for every collision. And, the most fun, Gauntlet racing, which fuses Hot Pursuits and Previews into one time trial mode, with a car the game gives you, and with brutal police force trying to stop you, while you use powerups to help you get rid of the cops. [Check out Equipment Section]Cop RacesAnd with cop, you have Hot Pursuits races, which is about busting between 5-7 cars, by ramming and using powerups. [Check Equipment Section] You have Rapid Response, a cop time trial, with penalties for collisions. And the most fun cop mode, Interceptor, which is like Hot Pursuits, but instead of focusing on busting 5-7 racers, it focuses on busting 1 super hard racer with the use of powerups. [Check Equipment Section]EQUIPMENTEquipment, which is basically powerups, are an easy way to separate arcade racing games from simulator racing games. There are 8 equipment in NFS: HP, 4 for each side.Racer EquipmentJammers, used to prevent cops from using their equipment.Spike Strips, which are used to blow cops or other racers tires, and also causes damage and disables them for a few seconds.EMP, to disable cops or other racers for a few seconds and also causes minor damage.Turbo, to give you a big boost in speed for a few seconds.Cop EquipmentRoadblocks, which can be called to make racers slow down, and cause damage.Spike Strips, which are used to blow racers tires, and also causes minor damage and disables them for a few seconds.EMPs, to disable racers for a few seconds and also cause minor damage.Helicopter Support, which can be called to deploy spike strips and use EMPs against the racers.CARSCars are unlocked for every bounty milestone. [Check out Bounty and Levels, in the Gameplay Section] There are 105 cars to unlock in total. The racers have 55 available cars, and the cops have 50, but most of them are copies from each other side. That means that most cop cars are the cars available for the racers, but with police paintjobs on them. And while there is no real customization in the game, the racers can choose the color they want for the car they pick (if the car allows for color customization). There are five types of car series for each side, SPORTS, PERFORMANCE, SUPER, EXOTIC, and HYPER.GAMEPLAYNFS: HP offers fast racing gameplay with tight controls. The racer/cop differences and the varied race types keep the game exciting to play. And the addition of equipment in some race types, and the strategy use of them, makes for an even better gameplay.Bounty and LevelsThere are 20 levels for each side, and you level up with bounty gained from winning races, completing milestones and completing challenges.WORLDSeacrest County is as gorgeous as it is diversed. You get to drive along beaches, drive through hot deserts, drift along the many corners of Snow Mountains, and drive really fast in highways packed with traffic.Free RoamThere is a free roam mode, where you can choose cars you have unlocked so far, but there is nothing to do in it, other than look at the car. I really, really think criterion missed a huge opportunity to make the free roam fun, like adding chases and stuff. Like if you were free roaming as a racer, and you were speeding, it would be cool if the cops came and tried to stop you, and you would get bounty to outrun or wreck them. And vice-versa, if you were free roaming as a cop, racers would speed by you really fast, and you would choose to chase them and wreck them to get bounty.PROSBeautiful landscapesDiverse worldGreat car unlock paceBig variety of cars Detailed world and car modelsGreat variety of race typesTight controls make for great gameplay MEHPoor vehicle customizationNo story or plotCONSWeak free roamCONCLUSIONI personally don’t find simulators fun, because that’s not why I play video games. I play video games to have fun and do something I can’t do in real life, like drive really fast, crash, and keep going after a few seconds, with no penalties. And that’s what this game is, a fun arcade racing game that throws in the occasional fun powerups. If that’s what you’re looking for, Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit  is a must buy.

												As a veteran NFS player I'll try to remain as bias as possible with this review.I originally got this game back in 2011 as a christmas gift. I loved it and played for close to a year before the copy of it I had (on the Xbox 360) was stolen from me by some former friends of mine. I enjoyed every moment of the game as I felt it brought NFS back to it's roots from the days of Need for Speed 3: Hot Pursuit and Need for Speed Hot Pursuit 2. I have always felt at home with the NFS series as it took racing to levels that most other games can't compete with. NFS has always been Cops versus Racers. However I see people on here writing reviews that they're angry there's no customization for the cars. Of course there isn't any Customization. NFS Underground and Underground 2 plus MW (Original) and MW (Remake) were the experiments of EA wanting to test their limits for NFS. NFS at it's Core has always been Cops versus Racers with exotic cars (Such as the Bugatti) or common cars (Ford Mustang, Dodge Charger, Nissan 370Z, etc.) with no customization. I enjoy this. This game is proof that the roots of a game are more important then appealing this current generation of NFS gamers. I have in total 17 years of NFS gametime. I feel at home here with this game. This is the NFS I've grown up to enjoy as a racing game. Yes some of the games released have no storylines. But NFS isn't about storylines. NFS is about having fun racing other people or your friends. It's about having a good time driving your dream cars. HP3 and HP2 had no storyline either and both were the epitome of NFS. I'll leave any Pros and Cons to those who choose to share them on a review. I'll continue to support EA and Criterion. As long as they continue to bring great NFS games I'll continue to purchase and play them.

I've logged plenty of hours, and plan to put more into it.This is a good game to just boot up, blast some tunes, let out some fumes, drift some corners, and rev some engines.

content:
ry 11, 2014
												Among the TOP Racing Games on Steam!Initially, I purchased Need for Speed: Hot Persuit for Xbox 360. As I played the game on console, I realized that it had a great story line, but the graphics were a bit drab. So after about 2 days of having the game, I sold it back to GameStop, purchasing a Steam Card, for the Summer Sale. Without thinking any further, I purchased the game on Steam, as I knew I wasn't feeling the full effect without playing it on PC.After playing the game for an hour or so on PC, I realized how high-detailed this game is, for it's time. Sure it's not the best game out there (comparing it to newer titles like Forza 5), but this game is indeed a graphical wonderland. The physics, the textures, the storyline, the price, are all a crucial factor when it comes to reviewing this game.The graphics, like I previously mentioned, are definitely better than I had anticipated (even on console. Can you believe that?). The shadow effects, textures, reslolution, anti-aliasing, everything seemed to be rather well-produced, compared to other games of it's time (ie: Grand Theft Auto 4).Story. I am not one who typically likes the storyline of Need For Speed titles, being they vary from title to title, but this one was one of the better ones. Rather than having to stick to a specific story, you have an option to merely choose your side; cops or crooks. Regardless which side you choose, it's a a ton of fun. The online experience is pretty good as well. I love playing games online, but I was a bit of a skeptic when it came to playing this game online. But after playing a few rounds, I felt that it was pretty addicting, to be honest. Atleast it didn't make me ragequit like COD games.Furthermore, the game was very well produced, weighing in at one of the top racing games, in my steam account. I have played a large amount of games between those on Xbox and on PC, and I would have to say this game is in the top 3. Cons: I think car customization should be offered, as that is a necessity in having the perfect car. Game gets a bit repetitive after some time, of continually doing the same runs. Online community is a bit dried up, compared to other online games. I would like to see some improvements made to this game for the full 100. For now, I would have to say: 85/100

												Well, I've been playing the Career mode of the game for a couple of hours and thought I'd share my experience with this game.My ExpectationsI've never actually played one of the Need For Speed games prior to this one. I used to play Burnout Legends on XBOX and was looking for a similar game on Steam. That's when I purchased this one, judging by the review it seemed the closest to Burnout Legends.Career ModeRacing game's Career mode is what I'm after, so I was really looking forward to the one in Need For Speed. No surprise here, it's about climbing the ladder and become a Most Wanted (or the cop version of it, haven't played it much, though). During your career you'll drive faster cars, perform more risky stunts, take more (intelligent) shortcuts and try to keep your opponents behind you.Very Hot PursuitThe game is very, very challenging. Very. If you think Burnout's Career mode is challenging, you've seen nothing yet. And I'm not talking about 80% through, I'm talking about 10-20%. This is both good and bad. With enough patience, you can improve your driving (and eventually beat the game). But it might just as well get you frustrated.Proper Game Controller Support, Anyone?I used to think that driving games would be played best with a computer driving wheel controller, but that was actually more difficult than it was fun. Playing Burnout Legends using the XBOX controller was nice, so I was looking forward to a proper Game Controller Support. Unfortunately, Need For Speed fails to deliver. Although the controller is supported out-of-the-box the button mapping and the overall controller sensitivity feels to fragile. Seriously, when I play a car racing game that's about risky driving maneuvers I don't want the controls to be configured as if I had a think piece of glass in my hand that'd brake anytime soon. Admittedly, that's very subjective, but maybe there are others that are looking for the same thing that I was.Cut The Videos, Please!In my career, all medals have to be gold. I don't know why, but I like to beat the score and finish the level, so to say. That's why I prefer cutscenes to be skip-able, restart the whole race quickly, load up a new level, etc. I've recently upgraded my setup and was expecting Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit to load and respond rather quickly. But the opposite is true: It takes f****ng ages to load, restart or quit a race. Seriously: Why does the game need to load (!) the whole map again when I just want to restart the race on the map that is already in memory?Sorry, but this is one of the biggest annoyances with this game for me.Speedwall? Forever Alone!After every race I'm presented with a Speedwall which I suppose is some kind of highscore. Only problem is: I'm the only one on that list. No one to compete with, not even strangers from the server. Only my score. Yes, I get it, the game is not the newest one available, and propably none of my friends even plays it. But then please let me challenges other players from around the globe and compare to some international ranking.tl;dr: Summary+ Very challenging+ Integrates with Big Picture+ Native XBOX 360 USB Controller support+ Nice graphics+ Great, motivating soundtrack+ Fun to play- Very challenging- XBOX 360 USB Controller configuration/sensitivity doesn't match a racing game- Shortcuts can be well-hidden and often require a good knowledge of the map- Autolog is annoying. Signing up for an account? - I'm logged in to Steam already!- Online leaderboard doesn't work or is not available- Incredible long (and unnecessary) loading processes, even for restarting only a race on that very same map. Seriously?

content:
er 29, 2014
												This is the first Need For Speed game I've played in years. I might've played one of the older ones on the PS2, and I know I played the original The Need For Speed (yes, "the" was part of the title at the time) back in 1994 on the 3DO. My point isn't to say, "look at what an old gamer I am," but instead to illustrate that I have relatively no way to compare this title againt contemporary NFS games. GRAPHICS:The visuals are fantastic! The cars shine and reflect light and other objects, the roads kick up dirt and dust, and there's a day/night cycle. There seems to be a distinct lack of anti-aliasing if you look closely, but given that you'll usually be going 300 KPH (that's 186 MPH) or so, you don't really have time to closely examine this. I imagine they decided to skip AA in favor of having higher framerates, which is more important in a high-speed racing game. Regardless, if you really need AA, you can always enable it through the Nvidia or ATI control panels. CAMERA:There is no cockpit mode, so you won't get to simulate actually being in the car or looking around at the inside of the cabin. The closest thing to this is a camera view that seems like you're looking from on top of the car's hood. You can also drive without any object on the screen except the speedometer, in addition to the standard "behind-the-car" view.Personally, I kind of miss the cockpit view. It's not a dealbreaker by any means, but it would've been nice to have.AUDIO:The game has plenty of engine rumbles and tires squealing. Really, the sound effects aren't anything noteworthy, but they're not bad either. The music annoys me, however. This NFS title has an in-game radio that you can't shut off without muting all music. Your only other options are to choose between "sequential" and "shuffle" modes for the music. Maybe this isn't an issue if you like the music in the game (I think all the songs are from real bands, but I don't know for sure; my musical tastes are still stuck in the 1980s), but if you don't, prepare to mute it all. It would've been nice if we could add our own MP3 tracks, and there might be a way to do that, but I wouldn't know how.HANDLING:This is a big one and probably the most subjective category. I think the cars handle great, but this is by no means a simulation. You're limited to accelerate, brake/reverse (hold the brake button down and the car shifts into reverse), the emergency brake, and oddly enough, the ignition, so you can actually turn your car on and off. You can also turn your headlights on or off, and if they're off when night rolls around, they switch on automatically. You can still turn them off then and drive around in the dark, but it doesn't really have an effect on the gameworld (i.e. drivers don't honk or flash their headlights at you).There's no way to change from an automatic transmission to a manual one in the game, despite most of the cars present probably have the latter or at least an option between the two. This doesn't really bother me as I always found a manual transmission to be distracting, but I know some people want it. DAMAGE:Your cars can and do take damage, although it's practically all cosmetic. You'll get plenty of nicks, scratches, and even dents, but nothing will break nor will any damage affect your car's ability to function. The one and only time damage actually matters is if you hit an object at a fast enough speed with enough force to cause a fatal crash. Then the game shows a little sequence and then you restart back on the road. CARS:What about the cars themselves? They're all real vehicles, fully licensed by the companies that make them. This is probably why damage is so limited. It's neat to see the real car brands, as opposed to thinly-veiled knockoffs, but other than some information when choosing the car itself or knowing you're driving such-and-such vehicle, it does little to enhance the game. MODIFICATION:This is strictly limited to paint color, and even that varies. Some cars don't even let you change the paint. You can't even change spoilers or headlights or tires, and you can forget about fine-tuning the engine. Again, this is more of an arcade game, not a simulation, so perhaps expecting that level of detail is a bit much. I know I didn't, but I've read some complaints about it before.STORY/CUTSCENES:There is no story. You simply play a speeder or a police officer, and have to complete missions and goals. When you do this successfully, you gain points (your "wanted level") which can be used to unlock new cars. The cutscenes are extremely annoying in that you can't skip them. This is particularly aggravating the first time you boot up the game, and each time you access a new area in the game itself. There are also a bunch of voiceovers, many of which occur when you select your vehicle. I think the automakers wanted a sales pitch to gamers and used this game as a way to do it.ACCOUNT:Yes, there's a required account. No, you don't need Origin, but it does want your EA/Origin email and password. Without that, you can't sign into the game's account service (called "Autolog") and thus can't play the game. It's slightly annoying, but if you already have an EA or Origin account, it's at least quick and easy to do. If you don't, then you'll have to sign up and that might be a hassle. VERDICT:I really like this game. It's not realistic, but it was never inteded to be either. If you want an arcade-like racing game that doesn't even pretend to have a storyline, and you don't mind using Autolog, I'd strongly recommend this game. On the other hand, if you want a hardcore simulation and detest the idea of signing into anything (except maybe Steam), you might want to pass this game up. It won't do anything for you and there are plenty of simulations available elsewhere.

content:

												There's a Wow factor to this game that tops anyother racing game. -8/10Personally, my favorite racing game of all time is Need for Speed MostWanted (Gamecube), funny enough this game is nothing like it. No open world to explore, no car customizations, no more cars that cost ingame money... nothing. But don't let this fool you. Criterion Games has built this to be a realisting, aracde like racing game. The gameplay is built to be fun and nothing else. The cars are free, so once they're unlocked go ahead and use them. The gamplay is easy to learn and is very balanced. The graphics are insane+car crashes are very amusing to watch. This is not what you'd expect from most NFS game but it might just be a whole lot better.Moving on the small issues I have with the game. First off, I have already mentioned the differences to other racing titles, and yes there are a lot of differences, but I really like the change of flavor. So thats not really a problem. Secondly, the game gets repetitive. You learn it quickly and after that, there's nothing else to learn. It's just the same kind of races over and over  again over again (#definitionofinsanityfarcry3). The last problem I have with the game is the time trials. I hate them, understand this.... you have to do perfectly on the course, take all the shortcuts, don't crash once then maybe you will get gold (the amount of bounty you get to level up depends on the medal placement the game uses). Even then it might not happen. I've been off by 0.03 seconds from getting gold, even worse, I've lost gold by 0.01s. Just stay away from the time trials and you will have a great experience.In the end it's your decision on whether you get this game or not, but I'm telling you this... if you buy this game, you will not regret it. Straight up, its fun. I recommend everyone to give this game a try. -8/10

Let's begin with the down sides to the game:-The Ai is too clingy and elastic, it will shoot right back at you.-The stats of the cars don't matter. I would recommed this game, but only slightly. The faults can be overlooked, but can get to you after a while.

1, 2014
												As a long time NFS Fan, and seeing the nonsense Critereon had done to my favorite racing franchise, I have to say... They actually did it right.Now, this isn't a game that's traditional to the NFS Franchise, there's no open world, and of course, you can play as the cops as well, but to me, this game is a lot like Carbon without the open world, and more fast paced and suspenseful than Carbon could of even dreamed of.~Pros+Driving in this game seems a lot more suspenseful and genuinely fun than other NFS titles (not all, however)+Drifting system in this game may not be realistic, but they absolutely nailed the drifting system for something arcade style.+Vehicle selection is absolutely awesome, the roster might not be as big as other titles, but I find I can drive every single car and enjoy it.+Multiplayer is absolutely -awesome-. there's much less lag than other NFS titles, and the Hot Pursuit mode is wicked fun.+Easy to pick up, put down, or play consistently, casual and hardcore friendly.+Keyboard support is phenomenal compared to other NFS titles, it doesn't feel like you NEED a wheel or controller.~Cons-No Open World-Multiplayer community is lacking (as all racing games suffer.) (matchmaking can take a while.)-Very limited graphics options (Is not old-pc friendly, but the awesome optimization from Dice allows for low-end PC's to run it fine at 30-60 fps with minimal frame drops)-Occasional frame drops on low end systems.~Toss-ups*Arcade style racing, this is NOT a sim.*Power-up style gameplay on some races, EMP's, Spike Strips, etc, this fits perfectly imo because of being able to play as police.*Drifting System is not realistic, however, imo, this the first game to nail an arcade style drifting system, no other game competes.*Cars auto-unlock in an order, all cars however remain driveable, there is no purchasing system, you get cars by getting reputation through driving and have access to all cars you have unlocked at all times.*Solid change-up from the traditional NFS franchise, however, imo, it's a very well done change-up, and is definitely a fun title worthy of being deemed Need For Speed.Imo, I absolutely love it, the frame drops can be tedious, but my system isn't very good, you may never get those, don't let my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ system discourage you. I also dislike the lack of an open world, however, there's so much veriety in this game I cannot find myself to get bored with this title, it's just awesome and I'm striving to hit those gold medals on every race, the arcade drifting system is insanely well done, and while some people might think of it as NFS meets Mario Kart, they're far from right, this has got to be the most fun action/racing combo I've ever played, and it blows every Burnout title out of the water.8.5/10

												Among the TOP Racing Games on Steam!Initially, I purchased Need for Speed: Hot Persuit for Xbox 360. As I played the game on console, I realized that it had a great story line, but the graphics were a bit drab. So after about 2 days of having the game, I sold it back to GameStop, purchasing a Steam Card, for the Summer Sale. Without thinking any further, I purchased the game on Steam, as I knew I wasn't feeling the full effect without playing it on PC.After playing the game for an hour or so on PC, I realized how high-detailed this game is, for it's time. Sure it's not the best game out there (comparing it to newer titles like Forza 5), but this game is indeed a graphical wonderland. The physics, the textures, the storyline, the price, are all a crucial factor when it comes to reviewing this game.The graphics, like I previously mentioned, are definitely better than I had anticipated (even on console. Can you believe that?). The shadow effects, textures, reslolution, anti-aliasing, everything seemed to be rather well-produced, compared to other games of it's time (ie: Grand Theft Auto 4).Story. I am not one who typically likes the storyline of Need For Speed titles, being they vary from title to title, but this one was one of the better ones. Rather than having to stick to a specific story, you have an option to merely choose your side; cops or crooks. Regardless which side you choose, it's a a ton of fun. The online experience is pretty good as well. I love playing games online, but I was a bit of a skeptic when it came to playing this game online. But after playing a few rounds, I felt that it was pretty addicting, to be honest. Atleast it didn't make me ragequit like COD games.Furthermore, the game was very well produced, weighing in at one of the top racing games, in my steam account. I have played a large amount of games between those on Xbox and on PC, and I would have to say this game is in the top 3. Cons: I think car customization should be offered, as that is a necessity in having the perfect car. Game gets a bit repetitive after some time, of continually doing the same runs. Online community is a bit dried up, compared to other online games. I would like to see some improvements made to this game for the full 100. For now, I would have to say: 85/100

content:
er 13, 2014
												Well, I've been playing the Career mode of the game for a couple of hours and thought I'd share my experience with this game.My ExpectationsI've never actually played one of the Need For Speed games prior to this one. I used to play Burnout Legends on XBOX and was looking for a similar game on Steam. That's when I purchased this one, judging by the review it seemed the closest to Burnout Legends.Career ModeRacing game's Career mode is what I'm after, so I was really looking forward to the one in Need For Speed. No surprise here, it's about climbing the ladder and become a Most Wanted (or the cop version of it, haven't played it much, though). During your career you'll drive faster cars, perform more risky stunts, take more (intelligent) shortcuts and try to keep your opponents behind you.Very Hot PursuitThe game is very, very challenging. Very. If you think Burnout's Career mode is challenging, you've seen nothing yet. And I'm not talking about 80% through, I'm talking about 10-20%. This is both good and bad. With enough patience, you can improve your driving (and eventually beat the game). But it might just as well get you frustrated.Proper Game Controller Support, Anyone?I used to think that driving games would be played best with a computer driving wheel controller, but that was actually more difficult than it was fun. Playing Burnout Legends using the XBOX controller was nice, so I was looking forward to a proper Game Controller Support. Unfortunately, Need For Speed fails to deliver. Although the controller is supported out-of-the-box the button mapping and the overall controller sensitivity feels to fragile. Seriously, when I play a car racing game that's about risky driving maneuvers I don't want the controls to be configured as if I had a think piece of glass in my hand that'd brake anytime soon. Admittedly, that's very subjective, but maybe there are others that are looking for the same thing that I was.Cut The Videos, Please!In my career, all medals have to be gold. I don't know why, but I like to beat the score and finish the level, so to say. That's why I prefer cutscenes to be skip-able, restart the whole race quickly, load up a new level, etc. I've recently upgraded my setup and was expecting Need For Speed: Hot Pursuit to load and respond rather quickly. But the opposite is true: It takes f****ng ages to load, restart or quit a race. Seriously: Why does the game need to load (!) the whole map again when I just want to restart the race on the map that is already in memory?Sorry, but this is one of the biggest annoyances with this game for me.Speedwall? Forever Alone!After every race I'm presented with a Speedwall which I suppose is some kind of highscore. Only problem is: I'm the only one on that list. No one to compete with, not even strangers from the server. Only my score. Yes, I get it, the game is not the newest one available, and propably none of my friends even plays it. But then please let me challenges other players from around the globe and compare to some international ranking.tl;dr: Summary+ Very challenging+ Integrates with Big Picture+ Native XBOX 360 USB Controller support+ Nice graphics+ Great, motivating soundtrack+ Fun to play- Very challenging- XBOX 360 USB Controller configuration/sensitivity doesn't match a racing game- Shortcuts can be well-hidden and often require a good knowledge of the map- Autolog is annoying. Signing up for an account? - I'm logged in to Steam already!- Online leaderboard doesn't work or is not available- Incredible long (and unnecessary) loading processes, even for restarting only a race on that very same map. Seriously?

content:
1, 2014
												As a long time NFS Fan, and seeing the nonsense Critereon had done to my favorite racing franchise, I have to say... They actually did it right.Now, this isn't a game that's traditional to the NFS Franchise, there's no open world, and of course, you can play as the cops as well, but to me, this game is a lot like Carbon without the open world, and more fast paced and suspenseful than Carbon could of even dreamed of.~Pros+Driving in this game seems a lot more suspenseful and genuinely fun than other NFS titles (not all, however)+Drifting system in this game may not be realistic, but they absolutely nailed the drifting system for something arcade style.+Vehicle selection is absolutely awesome, the roster might not be as big as other titles, but I find I can drive every single car and enjoy it.+Multiplayer is absolutely -awesome-. there's much less lag than other NFS titles, and the Hot Pursuit mode is wicked fun.+Easy to pick up, put down, or play consistently, casual and hardcore friendly.+Keyboard support is phenomenal compared to other NFS titles, it doesn't feel like you NEED a wheel or controller.~Cons-No Open World-Multiplayer community is lacking (as all racing games suffer.) (matchmaking can take a while.)-Very limited graphics options (Is not old-pc friendly, but the awesome optimization from Dice allows for low-end PC's to run it fine at 30-60 fps with minimal frame drops)-Occasional frame drops on low end systems.~Toss-ups*Arcade style racing, this is NOT a sim.*Power-up style gameplay on some races, EMP's, Spike Strips, etc, this fits perfectly imo because of being able to play as police.*Drifting System is not realistic, however, imo, this the first game to nail an arcade style drifting system, no other game competes.*Cars auto-unlock in an order, all cars however remain driveable, there is no purchasing system, you get cars by getting reputation through driving and have access to all cars you have unlocked at all times.*Solid change-up from the traditional NFS franchise, however, imo, it's a very well done change-up, and is definitely a fun title worthy of being deemed Need For Speed.Imo, I absolutely love it, the frame drops can be tedious, but my system isn't very good, you may never get those, don't let my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ system discourage you. I also dislike the lack of an open world, however, there's so much veriety in this game I cannot find myself to get bored with this title, it's just awesome and I'm striving to hit those gold medals on every race, the arcade drifting system is insanely well done, and while some people might think of it as NFS meets Mario Kart, they're far from right, this has got to be the most fun action/racing combo I've ever played, and it blows every Burnout title out of the water.8.5/10

												This version of Need for Speed was very different the first few older Need for Speed titles. In this installment they added "weapons" to the racer and the cop. This wouldn't be such a problem if they had balanced them in some sort of way. They always seemed to work really well for the racer, but on the other hand, cops didn't have as good weapons. Although they were different, they never worked out well. The racers had weapons that would in a since, "deal damage" to the cop or aid in there escape. Cops had weapons that would help stop or slow down a racer. Makes since right? Well it really shouldn't have been a problem besides playing with only 1 person (which I find to be the only way to play it seeing as the multi-player is basically dead.) Playing with only 1 other person would make it have to be cop v. racer. Racer usually has the upper hand, mainly because it starts you off in the lead although the cops can usually catch up pretty quickly. Overall I enjoy playing it. I definitely suggest you buy it.

												Need for speed Hot Pursuit, is a game that I've invested about 30H on, had this game on playstation, got it for only 20€ back in 2011, the game didnt sell well, it was a different style from the trending roots back in the 2000's, it had decent critics, around 8/10, brought it again a few days ago for only 3€ (dirt cheap).My opinion, pros and cons about the game.Pros:-Most cars have a solid sound;-The driving feels soft (can be a con);-Graphics are still pretty;-Has a good variaty of cars;-Has the Carrera GT and Mclaren F1;-The online is pretty much the best ever;-American cars look and sound Murican to me;-Cops are actually challenging, not dummies like NFS 2k15.Cons:-Lambos drive like toys and sound like toys, forget the bull side of things;-AI is sometimes the biggest noob ever, but sometimes your driving a faster car a top speed but they still get you;-70% racer cars are convertibles, personal taste, barelly noticeble but ffs Convertible Reventon, Veyron, 370Z, Zonda,                  Viper, Corvette, Lambos, etc...what were they thinking?!?!?;-No actual player base;-Grinding the few first classes, were a pain;-Low end cars are all the same (driving last race is long but still would have rather have a story written by a potato.Real Talk:So lets trash talk a bit, this game is by no means even worth 5€, i had this brought for me and gifted to a 												Need for speed Hot Pursuit, is a game that I've invested about 30H on, had this game on playstation, got it for only 20€ back in 2011, the game didnt sell well, it was a different style from the trending roots back in the 2000's, it had decent critics, around 8/10, brought it again a few days ago for only 3€ (dirt cheap).My opinion, pros and cons about the game.Pros:-Most cars have a solid sound;-The driving feels soft (can be a con);-Graphics are still pretty;-Has a good variaty of cars;-Has the Carrera GT and Mclaren F1;-The online is pretty much the best ever;-American cars look and sound Murican to me;-Cops are actually challenging, not dummies like NFS 2k15.Cons:-Lambos drive like toys and sound like toys, forget the bull side of things;-AI is sometimes the biggest noob ever, but sometimes your driving a faster car a top speed but they still get you;-70% racer cars are convertibles, personal taste, barelly noticeble but ffs Convertible Reventon, Veyron, 370Z, Zonda,                  Viper, Corvette, Lambos, etc...what were they thinking?!?!?;-No actual player base;-Grinding the few first classes, were a pain;-Low end cars are all the same (driving terms);-The velocity aspect is all ♥♥♥♥ed up, going at 300km/h feels like 100km/h IRL;-No story, feels like a kid smacked his head into the keyboard and typed Autolog.-10H single player, no Rival, the last race is long but still would have rather have a story written by a potato.Real Talk:So lets trash talk a bit, this game is by no means even worth 5€, i had this brought for me and gifted to a friend, so at least i had someone to compete with, do not buy this game alone, the game does not create any nostalgia, i played it a few years back but had no interest in playing it ever again until i saw it for 3€, the community is pretty much dead, no one plays it, got a full queue for a few hours but hard to find anyways and you have to grind the single player to get decent cars in multiplayer that nobody plays.Need for speed story:I've played pretty much every decent NFS, Underground, Underground 2, Most wanted, Carbon, Prostreet (not that great), Undercover (barelly any play time), Shift (barelly any play time), Most wanted (2012) and NFS 2015, you can see that im not new to the scene, i just didnt play the older ones, because my dad didnt introduce me into them, im only 16 and i've had almost every NFS since i can remember (was too young).I rate this game a solid:8/10 in 20104.5/10 in 2017

												A great addition to my favourite videogame franchise.I've been playing need for speed games since Need For Speed: Most Wanted in 2005. Hot pursuit offers a lot of enjoyment. I previously played this game on my PS3, and when I saw it on sale for £4, I gave in to the temptation of buying it for PC.The game, one of the newest in the franchise, let's you compete in events around the fictional "Seacrest County" as either cop or racer. Each faction has a variety of events. For cops, it's shutting down races, going one-on-one with a racer or rapid deployment. For racers, events included races (obviously), hot pursuits (a race in which cops try to wreck you) and time trials.However, there is no free-roam career mode, as there is in other NFS games (such as most wanted, rivals and carbon), which is a real shame. Also, despite there being 20 levels, you unlock all events by the time you are Level 11-12, which means you are replaying the same events over and over again.The game has good G27 support, if a little loose compared to other games, but you get used to itFor £15 though, you will most likely get a good 10-20h of enjoyment. I will recommend Mostwanted (2005 and 2012) and rivals over this though, considering they are the same price.

Could it have been that difficult to program the A.I. to go for, say, first place?-Ridiculous Difficulty Curves. Why is it that the Cop levels are so obnoxiously more difficult than the Racer ones? The hardest part of getting the trophy for all golds were the Cop levels, most notably, the Time Trials. These are the most unforgiving levels. Most times you can only just manage to beat the gold by perhaps 5 seconds max, and thats with zero ♥♥♥♥ ups. The worst part is that the Racer ones are a breeze.-Poor physics. Perhaps the most agregious thing in this game is the physics engine. You will swear up and down on your life that you never even touched the car you past, but yet you still get a "Crashed" mini cutscene. Other times you slam into a car at 200mph and nothing happens. You just bulldoze 'em out of the way like it was nothing.-Driving. I don't know who did the "weight" for the vehicles but I hope you don't program racing games anymore. Your car will more times than not feel like someone trying to slide a brick down a hill. Your car will turn at bare minimum, maybe 5 degrees a second. So you have to brake and drift, but you lose so much speed in that half second you braked you might as well just turn regularly. However the A.I. will always SPEED UP when drifting. What the hell, man.In all, this game is pretty to look at and you'll probably like it for the first few races, but its all downhill after that, sadly.

er 25, 2013
												This is an odd entry to me in the NFS franchise. It's a reboot of an old series, the last of which was one of my favorite childhood games, with some of the elements of later games and very little of the fun from the originals. It feels like they tried for realism (more on that in a bit) and sacrificed fun in the processes. Hot Pursuit 2 (2002) had you dodging flaming barrels dropped from helicopters while this one has dramatic crash cams. There is no customization, absolutely no reason to jump into the open world, and zero plot. I'm sure this is an affect of the move to Criterion who seem to think every racing game fan wants nothing more than shiny cars and big crashes.Perhaps the strangest issue is the driving physics. They are just plain wrong. Essentially they are setup to slide around every corner which makes fine control something of an impossibility. This really becomes a problem when the game starts penalizing you for touching walls and traffic in time trials.The games saving grace is the ability to play as a cop and bust up races. In these cases the constantly interrupting crash cams seem justified and are satisfying compared to frustrating when you hit an oncoming car for the n-th time while your car slides instead of turns.In the end I can't recommend this game, even on sale. There is little depth so it quickly becomes bland and repetitive, getting to the end turns into a grind.

												Wow!!! What can I say?  This is one full-on arcade racer.  Need for Speed Hot Pursuit bears all the hallmarks of a Criterion Games racer :  - Eye watering visuals  - Brain melting speed   - Nerve shattering crashesSo far I have found this racer very (very) enjoyable.   It's not the hardest arcade racer out there, but I'm not very far in so maybe I just need to give it more time.  However it is thoroughly enjoyable.  The drift mechanics can feel a little floaty at the beginning, but once you master them they give a very satisfying drift that makes you feel like the proverbial Dominic Toretto.  Most racers punish you if you crash, this game rewards you in spades.  The weighty impact of each crash is so satifying that you keep doing it just to jolt your nerves one more time.I'd forgotten how much I love the 'Cops and Robbers' game play of the Hot Pursuit games and this does not disappoint in this area.  Being the criminal means you get to show those law enforcing numties what proper high speed driving looks like and as a cop you get to bring those cocky lawbreaking scumbags to a sticky end.  If you liked the Burnout, Need for Speed or Flatout games then this racer will hit all your sweet spots.  If your new to arcade racers get it anyway and you'll instantly become a super fan.I'd say that at £14.99 this game represents very good value for money, but at £2.99 (the current sale price Feb 2017) buying this game is a no-brainer.  Do it! You owe it to yourself.  Finally you can release all that road rage that's been building up inside you during the grinding commutes to and from work.

												Overall this game fails due to the cheating rubber band AI. Why have faster cars when the AI will cheat and fly past you with a slower car? Despite all the cheating to AI fails to provide much of a challenge. Sometimes the AI will even get so high speed boost into a corner, that they have no chance of making the turn and instead wall ride / bounce of the walls to make the turn.Some of the negative things I faced in this game:The way takedowns of opponents and cops can cause some really annoying and confusing situations. Sometimes I'd bust racers as a cop, when after a previous cutscene spawned me directly on a crash course with another racer. Coming out of a crash cutscene can also cause you to be heading towards a wall with almost no time to recover. The way these crashes get triggered also seems quite random at times. Sometimes you'll be crashing with traffic almost head on at 200km/h only to have your speed reduced. Other times hitting something at much lower speed will trigger a crash.Taking down cops as a racer also seems to be quite pointless. In many cases the game will simply spawn more and more cops to chase you, thus turning the takedowns into nothing more but some extra points for advancing your rank.The handling differences of the cars within a certain series are basically nonexistent. Sure, this isn't meant to be a simulation, but it would be nice if your car selection would have any impact on the handling at all. Now they all feel basically the same.I also randomly experienced some odd performance slowdowns  that fixed themselves after a couple of seconds.Positive things about the game:Unlike many other modern NFS games, this does actually have a bonnet  camera. Thus you aren't forced to use the back camera like in many other games in the series. Yes, those games do have the bumper camera, but I consider that to be useless as it's so low that you cannot see anything even if there's a slighthest hill on the road.You can turn of the damn siren, even during a chase event. There's no point in having it on IMHO since it has no effect on the traffic anyway. For example some events in Rivals force you to have the siren on.The soundtrack is decent enough. It does have some really good tracks like Watercolour by Pendulum.There aren't long unskippable cutscenes, I wish though that those that are in the game could be skipped.

												Overall this game fails due to the cheating rubber band AI. Why have faster cars when the AI will cheat and fly past you with a slower car? Despite all the cheating to AI fails to provide much of a challenge. Sometimes the AI will even get so high speed boost into a corner, that they have no chance of making the turn and instead wall ride / bounce of the walls to make the turn.Some of the negative things I faced in this game:The way takedowns of opponents and cops can cause some really annoying and confusing situations. Sometimes I'd bust racers as a cop, when after a previous cutscene spawned me directly on a crash course with another racer. Coming out of a crash cutscene can also cause you to be heading towards a wall with almost no time to recover. The way these crashes get triggered also seems quite random at times. Sometimes you'll be crashing with traffic almost head on at 200km/h only to have your speed reduced. Other times hitting something at much lower speed will trigger a crash.Taking down cops as a racer also seems to be quite pointless. In many cases the game will simply spawn more and more cops to chase you, thus turning the takedowns into nothing more but some extra points for advancing your rank.The handling differences of the cars within a certain series are basically nonexistent. Sure, this isn't meant to be a simulation, but it would be nice if your car selection would have any impact on the handling at all. Now they all feel basically the same.I also randomly experienced some odd performance slowdowns  that fixed themselves after a couple of seconds.Positive things about the game:Unlike many other modern NFS games, this does actually have a bonnet  camera. Thus you aren't forced to use the back camera like in many other games in the series. Yes, those games do have the bumper camera, but I consider that to be useless as it's so low that you cannot see anything even if there's a slighthest hill on the road.You can turn of the damn siren, even during a chase event. There's no point in having it on IMHO since it has no effect on the traffic anyway. For example some events in Rivals force you to have the siren on.The soundtrack is decent enough. It does have some really good tracks like Watercolour by Pendulum.There aren't long unskippable cutscenes, I wish though that those that are in the game could be skipped.

7, 2014
												I enjoy an action-based racing game once in a while, the NFS games were always fulfilling that desire of mine. Until now. Hot Pursuit was really promising, since the last NFS I played was the first Most Wanted. Now you could play as cops as well, which sounded to me that this game would be everything Most Wanted was and more. Sadly, that's not true.The first thing that really bugged me was the whole online-registration thing. My friends don't play this game and I don't want to be forced to be able to use the online-functions. After that you jump right into the game. You choose an event, you race it and so on. Your first car is already a Porsche, you can choose it's color and that's it. Thorughout the first 2 hours of this game you have already unlocked so many cars, it's almost ridiculous. There's no "career mode", where you save up to buy a car or to tune your car the way you want it. You just get the cars. And what's the point of taking pictures of your car and sharing them with your friends when you can't make your car look unique?It's sad, the racing part is actually quite fun but without the whole "open world", career-thing that makes you value your cars, it just feels like a series of test-drives, since I really don't see how you would do 2 races in a row with the same car, when you unlock a new car every race.I know that you will actually pick your cars carefully later on in the game, it's just that it's more fun imo to have those few cars you bought and specialized to chose from rather than every car that's in the game.I really did expect a lot more from this game and I can't see why they left out the whole car-specializing and open world part. The best thing in Most Wanted was, after finishing a race being chased by cops, that you would have to lose the heat even after the race. Now it just stops when you cross the finish line. Sad.Edit: Of course it feautres the EA-exklusive unskippable "cutscenes" and player unfriendly gameplay mechanics as well as the ridiculously overdriven sound "effects". But hey, at a Lamborghini exklusive event you can choose between 3 almost identical Lamborghinis! That's something, right?Edit 2: I'm definitely done playing this game for good. I just had a race, where the last part is almost one long straight road, I escaped from a crash site where every other racer-car was standing still, I put on the turbo, continued with 400 km/h and powered the turbo again for the last few meters and suddenly two race-cars dash in front of me and I end up being 2nd. I don't know why but EA seems to be in charge of how a race should develop and result. There's no way another car would have been able to come even close to me when they all just had been in an accident.

content:

PROS:+ great soundtrack+ fun arcade racing+ two different career modes - cop & racer+ lots of unlockables and rewards+ plenty of race tracks+ lots of cool cars+ partial gamepad supportCONS:- occasional drop in FPS or stutter  - requires EA account for multiplayer- online multiplayer is dead- no wheel supportComment:Need For Speed 3 - Hot Pursuit came out in 1998 and is a BIG part of why I got into PC gaming. Later they released Need For Speed (6) - Hot Pursuit 2 but that wasn't as great as the first one. Then the series branched out into various ways in the yearly releases. Until this reboot came back to the roots of silly arcade gameplay without the hassle of forcing in a story campaign. Back to funky shortcuts. For me it was the most fun NFS after a long while. Racer and cop careers are sepparate from each other. And you can rise in rank for both modes. You get experience for cool stuff you did even if you fail a mission/race. This feels good because it gives you a sense of progression every time play. You unlock new cars and items for every milestone you hit. Freedrive in each of the tracks is a nice option too - to try out the terrain or just casually drive around to relax. Social aspects were more of an experiment and while not needed at all they do have some quirks. Like why is it not possible to set an avatar but the only way to have a profile picture is to have a webcam connected. Online multiplayer is basically dead but then again I never played much of it, the singleplayer was all I really needed in this game. Played a lot of it back in the day and actually finished both modes. My favourite time to play was during long train trips where I would play on my laptop. That being said, this game is MUCH better with a gamepad. But gotta give it credit that both careers are doable on keyboard. Graphics are kind of clunky compared to the racing games of today but it personally doesn't bother me. Overall a cool and fun racing game that is worth a try but due to how old it is I recommend grabbing it on a sale.P.S.: I played waaay more than half an hour of this game, I just tried if it works here on Steam

10, 2016
												This is probably one of the best recent Need for Speed games, of not, the best of the series. With a wide variety of real world cars, instead of being realistic simulation, Hot Pursuit takes a very arcade-y route. Cars in this game are encouraged to demolish each on the race track, by shear force or its absurd weaponry of EMPs and spike strip deployers.I could talk about the cons of this game like no interactive open world, no customizability, dozens of camera/sound/visual glitches, limited gameplay, no slit screen , repeativeness, dead multiplayer, EA Autolog, lack of soul but the pros outweigh these cons. The graphics in this game still holds up, I can't believe this game was made 6 years ago. The cars all handle the same but that just adds to playability for newer players. The sound design (although buggy sometimes) is great, the engines sound so good and the turbo sound effect is so cool. Music is good but it's not a long playlist. There's a lot of cars (no Ferrari though). You can play both campaigns as a cop or racer. And if you ever get friends with this game, the online is fun as hell.It's not a perfect game but it is one of my favorites. It's almost a guilty pleasure, except this game is actually great. Just turn off your brain when you play this game it's literally a Michael bay film. Arcade-y, comically absurd, action packed and extremely enjoyable.

content:
y 16, 2016
												When I was a wee little kid one of my first racing games was Need for Speed 3: Hot Pursuit. It was fun. The way the title was written I always thought it was Need for Speed Hot Pursuit 3, and so I wondered why Hot Pursuit 2 was better in every way, but it was fun. Then I got Hot Pursuit 2 on PC AND PS2 because it was that freaking good. I played the crap out of that game, and it was always fun to return home from school to race while avoiding the police.What seperates Hot Pursuit from other racing games? The cops. In Need for Speed: Hot Pursuit, not only are you racing other cars, but you also have to worry about the police who will do everything in their power to shut the race down. This includes slamming your car all over the road, pinning it into corners, setting up roadblocks ahead, dropping spikestrips to flatten your tires, and calling a helicopter to find ways to ensure that even in the air they can ruin your day. It's not just a racing game, but an action survival game as you wreck cop cars and escape from the police like it's Fast and Furious. Which like the movies, Need for Speed is all about the rule of cool trope. Why is that cop chasing you in a Lamborghini? Because it's awesome, that's why.At the time this game came out I thought Need for Speed was a dead franchise. I had no idea this game and others existed. I only recently found out about this some months ago, and waited for a sale to pick this up. Now I was hesitant to get this reboot of the series considering what happened when Red Alert 3 was made (to make a long story short, it wasn't very good, and Red Alert 2 was one of my favorite games from my childhood as well), so I came in with low expectations. But holy cow was I ever surprised that they didn't mess this game up.It's still Hot Pursuit. But, it's Hot Pursuit on crack! Let me go over some of the differences between Hot Pursuit 2 and this game.1) In Hot Pursuit 2, the police had no way to bust you other than to be within a certain distance for a certain amount of time while you are below a certain speed. Once they do this three times, you're out of the race. In this reboot, rather than having strikes you have a health bar. All the cops (as well as other racers, pedestrians, and the enviroment) have to do is destroy your car. Granted your health is fairly beefy, but it IS possible to take down to zero, and in later parts of the game this happened quite frequently. This is a welcome change as it makes good driving skills much more important, as well as easing the OP'ness of the racers.2) In Hot Pursuit 2, spikestrips were static. A cop would request permission to place it, get approved, and then one would spawn ahead in a set location. The police would then announce on the radio where it was and what side of the road it was on. It was essentially a less visible roadblock. In Hot Pursuit 2010 the racers AND police have spikestrips, and they are deployables. When playing offline, I never noticed other racers using spikestrips, but that was fine by me as the police did more than fill that gap. What a cop will do is drive ahead of you, pull out in front, and then drop a strip. So if you see a cop pass you by, try to get as far away from the back of his car as possible. This makes spikestrips much more interesting as they can be anywhere at anytime, and you have to be able to adapt. It's never impossible to dodge them, but it does get trickier as you progress, because all "gadgets" have upgrades. So that means a cop may drop multiple strips.3) Gadgets. Hot Pursuit 2 had you and the cars. This game, as you play and unlock them, has upgradable gadgets and a "nitro" system. At first I thought it was completely unneccesary, but they sure do make things a lot more interesting. Especially in the longer courses. You have a nitro that fills up as you do risky stuff. Using the nitro will give you a burst of speed as long as you have the nitro to do it. You have a turbo that's nitro on crack, though it doesn't have a bar. You have a set number of uses, it makes you go extremely fast, and its length is out of your control. You'll be stuck in turbo until it's over. EMP allows police and racers to disable your car for a second. As you improve in the game you'll be able to jam EMP, dodge the lock-on, and correct your car while it's trying to spin out so that little-to-no-damage is done. So there's a degree of skill and conserving resources. I mentioned how you can drop spike strips already. Finally there's the jammer, which will block EMPs and allow you to see incoming roadblocks.4) The courses in Hot Pursuit 2 were seperate tracks with laps, like in every other racing game. In this reboot, you have a world map, but unlike Burnout Paradise where you never know where to go unless you painstakenly memorize EVERYTHING, the courses will be constructed for you out of this map. Also, instead of laps, you have a start and end point. This means that during a race you won't be seeing the same sights over and over again as you do laps. It keeps the race feeling fresh each time, with any degree of recognition being from an alternate route you took in another race.5) Takedowns and crashes. In Hot Pursuit 2, if you hit a wall or another car, then you just stop, reverse, and continue going. Here though it's like my two favorite racing games (Burnout 3 and NFS: Hot Pursuit 2) had a love child. If you've played Burnout, then you know what happens when you crash into something. Your car gets wrecked, massive damage is taken from your health, and you're put back on the road ready to go. But by then the other racers are past you. As with point number 1, this encourages better driving. It also makes races without cops much more exciting. In old Need for Speed, I could never understood why people would play with the cops turned off. It's just a run of the mill racing game then. But now, it becomes classic Burnout, and that's not a bad thing. I wasn't a fan of Paradise City, so something more like the older games where I could focus on racing rather than opening the map screen every couple of seconds to check where I should turn is more than welcome.Now I see in other reviews there are unskippable cutscenes. I have no idea what they are talking about. I skip them all the time. The only unskippable thing that occurs is the brief (like, 1-2 seconds maximum) scenes where it introduces a new cop car coming for you that you haven't seen before in previous races, when you total another racer or cop, or when your EMP/Spike Strip hits someone. Which, once again, is very brief. And Hot Pursuit 2 had the same thing. In fact, it was worse in HP2 because you would lose control of your car and there was no redirection. So if you were coming up to a turn or about to hit a strip or something and a camera snippit was shown, then you'd hit what was in front of you, no questions asked. At least here the game will steer your car for you while this is happening. And it does a great job at that too. Making turns better than I could, avoiding cars and police blockades and stuff by itself, etc. It has never screwed me over to give up control for 2 seconds, unlike in Hot Pursuit 2.Now, what complaints do I have? The soundtrack isn't as good as HP2, but with Steam Music I fixed that problem easily. That thing works great for racing games.The only other thing I find dissapointing is that there is no custom race mode. I can't create a path or even pick one to race on how I want. I can't pick a path, set whether I want cops to be there or not, set gadgets on or off (a lot of races don't even have the gadgets, but most of the ones with the cops chasing you do), set time of day, etc. I have to pick from premade "events", and level up my bounty (which isn't hard at all. Very anti-grindy actually. But it's still there) to unlock the events that I want to do. A custom race mode would have made this perfect. Otherwise, solid 8/10.

content:
y 19, 2015
												I must say that I was unpleasantly surprised by this title in the Need For Speed series. Luckily I bought it during a Steam Sale. I've finished the game in a less than 10 hours (probably even a hour or 2 less as I go AFK mid-games sometimes) without any struggling, and I'm not a professional when it comes to racing games. But most importantly: there is no reason to come back and play it again at all after completing the ''campaign''. After finishing the campaign, you unlock every car automatically and there is nothing else you can work towards to (there even aren't any Steam achievements). There is an option to play online against other players, but there aren't enough (if any) other players for this game anymore and therefore the racing against others online option is dead. You can queue for an online game, wait a hour, and still find out that none else will join it. You can also compare your racing-times with other players, but only with friends who also happen to play the game. How ridiculous is that?! You also can't customize the easily-earned cars, except for picking a new full-body color for only some cars, unlike other games in the NFS-series including NFS: Undercover. As for the positive factors, that would mostly be the graphics and crash-scenes. I wouldn't ever buy this game for over € 5,-. Even for a € 5,- price-tag I'd still have my thoughts whether it's worth it. Anyway, here is my list of pros and cons with a bit of extra stuff in it.Pros: - Great graphics- Great crashing-scenes- Great police-chases and escapes (helicopter interceptions, barricades, awesome!)- You can destroy other cars (so can yours be)- Easily learnt how to play itCons:- Every. single. car. is automatically and easily earned by finishing the not-challenging-at-all campaign (only the final 2 missions are a bit challenging, though still easy)- No customization options (only some cars can get a different full-body paint-job, that's all.) (There also isn't even a single customization option for the police cars)- There is a leveling system which has no purpose at all. I think it's only there to make you feel like you still earned something after losing a race (which you will rarely lose). The leveling system offers you slightly upgraded (and no different) weapons for your car. You will earn those ''upgraded'' weapons automatically during the campaign anyway. - Racing-routes are getting used over and over during the campaign, not once, not twice, no, sometimes you're driving the same road for up to like 8 different missions. - Racing-routes all look somewhat the same. No special jumps or whatsoever. Just one route has more curves than the others.- You play as two different roles during the entire game. Sometimes as the police officer, sometimes as the wanted person. But both roles earn the exact same car, except that you get sirens when being the police officer. Worst of all, because of that, you earn every single car in the game twice. So you've finished a mission, and what is your reward? ''Oh hey, it's the Lamborghini again which I've won earlier in this campaign as well, just this time with sirens on its roof''.- Sometimes the weather changes into a thunderstorm, but the amount of lightning during the thunderstorms is ridiculous. Lightning flashes every second. (awful if you're seizure-sensitive)- The online community is completely dead. Barely anyone plays the game online, sometimes you can sit in a queue (room) for up a to a hour and still not see any other player.- There is also no reason to play online, it does not earn you anything and you can't compare your stats with other online players. You can only compare your stats with friends. - There is nothing else to work towards to after finishing the campaign, there even aren't any Steam achievements, and there is no point in trying to set a better racing-time as you can't compare the stats online.- The physics are different (awful?) compared to the other NFS titles. You will (almost) never get off the ground with your car, no matter how big the bump in the road is. There are 2 or 3 bumps in the entire game (which you can even skip) which gets you only slightly off the ground, but you won't even notice that if you blinked. Steering also works awful compared to the other NFS titles. If you steer for a millisecond and tap the brake for a millisecond, you can get through any curve and you can perform a burn-out for the rest of the race. The only way to get out of the burnout is by driving 99% straight forward. If you're steering even slightly (10%) left or right, you'll stay in a burnout. - When you crash, you actually don't crash. A cut-scene with a crash pops up whenever you hit something else hard enough, and once the cut-scene ends you're just somehow driving at full speed and perfectly straight on the road. - Campaign is very repetitive. You'll barely notice any difference between the first mission, the final mission and everything in between. - Every mission uses the exact same cut-scene, both at the start and in the end. - (small con) When you start up the game, you have to sit through some of the credits and wait for them to pass by; you can't skip them. - You can abuse bugs by crashing your car at certain moments. For example, if there is a roadblock up ahead, you can 1 mile beforehand hit the guardrail to trigger a crashing cut-scene; the crashing cut-scene lets you completely bypass the roadblock.- The game can be finished within a few hours, even if you're entirely new to racing games. There is no reason to come back unless you'd like to start the campaign over againOut of 10, I'd rate it 5,5. The awesome police-chases and escapes is what compensates it just enough to be able to say that ''it's an ok game''. But I'm excluding the price for that rating. If I'd include the price, I'd definitely not recommend it to others. The amount of hours you can/will spend on this game simply isn't worth € 15,-. It'd be € 5,- max. But if you ''just want to try'' this game out, I wouldn't even pay € 5,-. Do it if you're a NFS-fan who's truly interested or otherwise get any of the other (even older) NFS titles. And if you really want police-chases, get the older, better, and cheaper NFS Undercover instead.
